                                                  Collapse Subdiscussion Ricky Liuna

                                                  Ricky Liuna

                                                  Sep 9, 2018 Sep 9, 2018 at 19:35
                                                  Hi Craig,   John is a con artist. John has black hair.Therefore, all people with black hair are con artists.   This one should be Fallacy of Composition because John's characteristic with black hairs is treated as representative of con artists group   Cheers,   Ricky
                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                  • Go To Parent

                                                  Hi Craig,

                                                   

                                                  John is a con artist. John has black hair.
                                                  Therefore, all people with black hair are con artists.

                                                   

                                                  This one should be Fallacy of Composition because John's characteristic with black hairs is treated as representative of con artists group

                                                   

                                                  Cheers,

                                                   

                                                  Ricky

                                                  Edited by Ricky Liuna on Sep 9, 2018 at 19:37
                                                  •
                                                    Paola Gonzalez Aguero

                                                    Paola Gonzalez Aguero

                                                    Sep 10, 2018 Sep 10, 2018 at 13:15
                                                    Hi Ricky,  This particular example fits better under guilt by association I think (this is also what the lecturer said during the chat). Guilt by association:  Two things share some properties, therefore they are the same In this case, just because John and "all people" share the "black hair" property, they are being treated as if they are the same (con artists) Cheers, Paola
                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                    • Go To Parent

                                                    Hi Ricky, 

                                                    This particular example fits better under guilt by association I think (this is also what the lecturer said during the chat).

                                                    Guilt by association:  Two things share some properties, therefore they are the same

                                                    In this case, just because John and "all people" share the "black hair" property, they are being treated as if they are the same (con artists)

                                                    Cheers,

                                                    Paola

                                                  Sonny Lo

                                                  Sonny Lo

                                                  Sep 4, 2018 Sep 4, 2018 at 6:44
                                                  I still do not understand how the active participation is assessed. I note you mentioned in the Weekly chat just posting tute answers is not sufficient for full marks. What about if I post tute answers and reply to another students post. Is it a 1% mark per week and then added up after 10 weeks. Or do you do an overall grading for this active participation for each student at the end of the subject. This is what I have:Activity 1:Premise: Downloading proprietary software (without permission from the copyright holder) is identical to stealing physical property.Premise: Stealing physical property is morally wrong.Conclusion: Therefore, downloading proprietary software (without permission) is morally wrong. INVALID: Stealing software and stealing physical propery are not the same but do have common factors such as unauthorised access/taking of another persons work/property, and denying the owners/software developers the right to profit. Software exists virtually and not physically.INDUCTIVE: It is highly probably that downloading proprietary software is morally wrong. Eg. 1: Valid, SoundEg. 2: Invalid, Fallacious (Premises are true, but conclusion is false)Eg. 3: Invalid, Fallacious. Counterexample: GPS satellites are wet if they fall from space and land in the ocean.Eg. 4: Valid, SoundEg. 5: Valid, Unsound (No one who plays piano watches footy matches is UNTRUE) Activity 2:Fallacy of Composition/divisionAd hominem: Attacking the politicians history instead of the policy; Straw man: Attempt to weaken the opponents position.Red herring: Saving the environment, and Adam and eve getting bored are unrelated.False dichotomy: Buying a book, and the importance of reading are not directly relatedSlippery slope: As the children will abuse the decision process; False cause fallacy: As Allowing the children the right to decide is an event that will trigger further future events on decision making.
                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                  • Go To Topic

                                                  I still do not understand how the active participation is assessed. I note you mentioned in the Weekly chat just posting tute answers is not sufficient for full marks. What about if I post tute answers and reply to another students post. Is it a 1% mark per week and then added up after 10 weeks. Or do you do an overall grading for this active participation for each student at the end of the subject. This is what I have:
                                                  Activity 1:
                                                  Premise: Downloading proprietary software (without permission from the copyright holder) is identical to stealing physical property.
                                                  Premise: Stealing physical property is morally wrong.
                                                  Conclusion: Therefore, downloading proprietary software (without permission) is morally wrong.

                                                  INVALID: Stealing software and stealing physical propery are not the same but do have common factors such as unauthorised access/taking of another persons work/property, and denying the owners/software developers the right to profit. Software exists virtually and not physically.
                                                  INDUCTIVE: It is highly probably that downloading proprietary software is morally wrong.

                                                  Eg. 1: Valid, Sound
                                                  Eg. 2: Invalid, Fallacious (Premises are true, but conclusion is false)
                                                  Eg. 3: Invalid, Fallacious. Counterexample: GPS satellites are wet if they fall from space and land in the ocean.
                                                  Eg. 4: Valid, Sound
                                                  Eg. 5: Valid, Unsound (No one who plays piano watches footy matches is UNTRUE)

                                                  Activity 2:
                                                  Fallacy of Composition/division
                                                  Ad hominem: Attacking the politicians history instead of the policy; Straw man: Attempt to weaken the opponents position.
                                                  Red herring: Saving the environment, and Adam and eve getting bored are unrelated.
                                                  False dichotomy: Buying a book, and the importance of reading are not directly related
                                                  Slippery slope: As the children will abuse the decision process; False cause fallacy: As Allowing the children the right to decide is an event that will trigger further future events on decision making.

                                                  •
                                                    Collapse Subdiscussion Mark Raffan

                                                    Mark Raffan

                                                    Sep 4, 2018 Sep 4, 2018 at 11:34
                                                    Looking through the list of common logical fallacies, it’s striking to me how it reads like a playbook for the worst kind of political debate. Or it's like the ultimate checklist for the script writer of a cliched attack ad. Almost every tweet in my Twitter feed fits neatly into one of two categories; either it's someone putting forward a logical fallacy or someone calling out another person for using a logical fallacy (sometimes unfairly, I think). Digging into some of them a bit deeper…   Appeal to authority: I think it's tough to avoid using this one, especially if you're not well-versed on the subject matter. In my head, it makes sense to defer to the experts but I can see how it could be used to jump to an unsound conclusion. One thing I've noticed is that a common rebuttal to an appeal to authority is an even more egregious fallacy. Here's an example off the top of my head. Person 1Premise: A study from XYZ University shows that crime in this city is at an all-time low.Conclusion: This is a safe city. Person 2Premise: I disagree, there were 3 robberies in my neighbourhood last week.Conclusion: This is an unsafe city. I'm not sure what variety of fallacious argument Person 2 is putting forward, but in my opinion it's at least as fallacious as Person 1's. Without wanting to start a furious debate, I'm wondering if people think if the below argument from Person 1 is a fallacious appeal to authority? Person 1Premise: There is a consensus among scientists that global warming is happening and it's the result of human activity.Conclusion: Global warming is happening and it's the result of human activity. To me it sounds like a reasonable argument, especially working with the assumption that the premise is true. I’m not a climate scientist so I'm happy to defer to the experts and take their opinion as my own. It's probably an invalid argument – even though there is a consensus among scientists, they might be wrong – but I think it's reasonably strong. At the very least, I think it's stronger than the common response. Person 2Premise: It's snowing outside and I've never been more cold.Conclusion: Global warming isn't happening. Again, I'm not sure how to define Person 2's fallacy but it seems be one – possibly anecdotal (https://yourlogicalfallacyis.com/anecdotal).   Ad Hominem: This is another one that I find difficult to avoid. Person X said Y, I don't like Person X, so Y can't be true or reasonable. Falling for this one makes if difficult to examine a claim on its merits.   Wrapping up… I just want to quickly mention 'gaslighting'. It's is a term I've heard a lot lately and seems to be relevant to this discussion. A clean definition is quite difficult to pin down, but I think it's a bit like the loaded question of statements. The classic loaded question being: Are you still beating your wife? It inserts something controversial or unproven into a question, assumes it is fact, and leaves the person being questioned in an impossible position. If they answer 'yes', they admit to something horrible. If they answer 'no', they leave open the implication they once did beat their wife. In a similar way, gaslighting (or one variety of it) inserts a controversial premise into a statement, treats it as fact, and messes with a person's ability to carry out step 6 (assess truth of premise) in the 7 step strategy for evaluating an argument. It'll often go something like this: As you all know, {insert controversial statement here}, so we really need to do X. Okay, I'll leave it here…
                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                    • Go To Topic

                                                    Looking through the list of common logical fallacies, it’s striking to me how it reads like a playbook for the worst kind of political debate. Or it's like the ultimate checklist for the script writer of a cliched attack ad.

                                                    Almost every tweet in my Twitter feed fits neatly into one of two categories; either it's someone putting forward a logical fallacy or someone calling out another person for using a logical fallacy (sometimes unfairly, I think).

                                                    Digging into some of them a bit deeper…

                                                     

                                                    Appeal to authority:

                                                    I think it's tough to avoid using this one, especially if you're not well-versed on the subject matter. In my head, it makes sense to defer to the experts but I can see how it could be used to jump to an unsound conclusion.

                                                    One thing I've noticed is that a common rebuttal to an appeal to authority is an even more egregious fallacy. Here's an example off the top of my head.

                                                    Person 1
                                                    Premise: A study from XYZ University shows that crime in this city is at an all-time low.
                                                    Conclusion: This is a safe city.

                                                    Person 2
                                                    Premise: I disagree, there were 3 robberies in my neighbourhood last week.
                                                    Conclusion: This is an unsafe city.

                                                    I'm not sure what variety of fallacious argument Person 2 is putting forward, but in my opinion it's at least as fallacious as Person 1's.

                                                    Without wanting to start a furious debate, I'm wondering if people think if the below argument from Person 1 is a fallacious appeal to authority?

                                                    Person 1
                                                    Premise: There is a consensus among scientists that global warming is happening and it's the result of human activity.
                                                    Conclusion: Global warming is happening and it's the result of human activity.

                                                    To me it sounds like a reasonable argument, especially working with the assumption that the premise is true. I’m not a climate scientist so I'm happy to defer to the experts and take their opinion as my own. It's probably an invalid argument – even though there is a consensus among scientists, they might be wrong – but I think it's reasonably strong.

                                                    At the very least, I think it's stronger than the common response.

                                                    Person 2
                                                    Premise: It's snowing outside and I've never been more cold.
                                                    Conclusion: Global warming isn't happening.

                                                    Again, I'm not sure how to define Person 2's fallacy but it seems be one – possibly anecdotal (https://yourlogicalfallacyis.com/anecdotalLinks to an external site.).

                                                     

                                                    Ad Hominem:

                                                    This is another one that I find difficult to avoid. Person X said Y, I don't like Person X, so Y can't be true or reasonable. Falling for this one makes if difficult to examine a claim on its merits.

                                                     

                                                    Wrapping up…

                                                    I just want to quickly mention 'gaslighting'. It's is a term I've heard a lot lately and seems to be relevant to this discussion. A clean definition is quite difficult to pin down, but I think it's a bit like the loaded question of statements.

                                                    The classic loaded question being: Are you still beating your wife? It inserts something controversial or unproven into a question, assumes it is fact, and leaves the person being questioned in an impossible position. If they answer 'yes', they admit to something horrible. If they answer 'no', they leave open the implication they once did beat their wife.

                                                    In a similar way, gaslighting (or one variety of it) inserts a controversial premise into a statement, treats it as fact, and messes with a person's ability to carry out step 6 (assess truth of premise) in the 7 step strategy for evaluating an argument. It'll often go something like this:

                                                    As you all know, {insert controversial statement here}, so we really need to do X.

                                                    Okay, I'll leave it here…

                                                    Edited by Mark Raffan on Sep 4, 2018 at 11:39
                                                    •
                                                      Maxwell Hollywood

                                                      Maxwell Hollywood

                                                      Sep 4, 2018 Sep 4, 2018 at 22:11
                                                      Do you consider robberies == unsafe?  Are they stealing or hurting people?  What qualifies safe, being able to move about unhindered and physically and emotionally ok?  Statistical data may prove that it's the safest city compared to statistical data from other cities, and the 3 robberies that occurred last week may just be part of that statistic or be an anomaly. Global warming isn't limited simply to just the globe getting warmer, there are side-effects and weather anomalies to go with it?  Scientists can be biased as well, a consensus is a "general agreement", implying that it is agreed upon by a majority, leaving a minority unaccounted for in the argument.
                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                      • Go To Parent

                                                      Do you consider robberies == unsafe?  Are they stealing or hurting people?  What qualifies safe, being able to move about unhindered and physically and emotionally ok?  Statistical data may prove that it's the safest city compared to statistical data from other cities, and the 3 robberies that occurred last week may just be part of that statistic or be an anomaly.

                                                      Global warming isn't limited simply to just the globe getting warmer, there are side-effects and weather anomalies to go with it?  Scientists can be biased as well, a consensus is a "general agreement", implying that it is agreed upon by a majority, leaving a minority unaccounted for in the argument.

                                                      •
                                                        Simon Jones

                                                        Simon Jones

                                                        Sep 7, 2018 Sep 7, 2018 at 1:24
                                                        Person 1Premise: There is a consensus among scientists that global warming is happening and it's the result of human activity.Conclusion: Global warming is happening and it's the result of human activity. I think authority fallacies are more focused on trusting a public or well known figure in a particular space, to be casting judgement or opinions (treated as fact) on a field they may not necessarily have expertise in. For instance, what if you changed the premise to: Premise: There is a consensus among top tennis players is happening and it's the result of human activity. Or being slightly more serious, what fields of science are we defining? It's a pretty broad spectrum. Technically branches of science include things like sociology and psychology. Would you have the same trust in the premise true, if instead of a generic scientist umbrella, it read: Premise: There is a consensus among psychologists that global warming is happening and it's the result of human activity.
                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                        • Go To Parent

                                                        Person 1
                                                        Premise: There is a consensus among scientists that global warming is happening and it's the result of human activity.
                                                        Conclusion: Global warming is happening and it's the result of human activity.

                                                        I think authority fallacies are more focused on trusting a public or well known figure in a particular space, to be casting judgement or opinions (treated as fact) on a field they may not necessarily have expertise in. For instance, what if you changed the premise to:

                                                        Premise: There is a consensus among top tennis players is happening and it's the result of human activity.

                                                        Or being slightly more serious, what fields of science are we defining? It's a pretty broad spectrum. Technically branches of science include things like sociology and psychology. Would you have the same trust in the premise true, if instead of a generic scientist umbrella, it read:

                                                        Premise: There is a consensus among psychologists that global warming is happening and it's the result of human activity.

                                                        •
                                                          Collapse Subdiscussion Sebastian Lamerichs

                                                          Sebastian Lamerichs

                                                          Sep 8, 2018 Sep 8, 2018 at 6:17
                                                          I've personally found it very useful to view "appeal to authority" as somewhat analogous to a correlation versus causation dispute.For this specific example, it's not that climate change is real because scientists say that it is (which is the logical structure of the claims made by Person 1 in both of Mark's appeal to authority examples), but rather that scientists say that climate change is real because it's real. What the scientists say has absolutely no effect on the existence of climate change, therefore it's not "correct" to use their word as evidence.Of course, it is possible to make logical steps in reverse there. In theory you could demonstrate that there is no reason why scientists would lie about this, and no way that they could be mistaken or misled. Therefore, the only way that scientists could possibly make that claim is if it was true. This just doesn't really come up much because if you can somehow prove that it's not possible for someone to be mistaken or to lie, you can probably prove the actual base claim ("climate change is real") a lot easier, and without having to involve any pesky psychology.
                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                          • Go To Parent

                                                          I've personally found it very useful to view "appeal to authority" as somewhat analogous to a correlation versus causation dispute.

                                                          For this specific example, it's not that climate change is real because scientists say that it is (which is the logical structure of the claims made by Person 1 in both of Mark's appeal to authority examples), but rather that scientists say that climate change is real because it's real. What the scientists say has absolutely no effect on the existence of climate change, therefore it's not "correct" to use their word as evidence.

                                                          Of course, it is possible to make logical steps in reverse there. In theory you could demonstrate that there is no reason why scientists would lie about this, and no way that they could be mistaken or misled. Therefore, the only way that scientists could possibly make that claim is if it was true. This just doesn't really come up much because if you can somehow prove that it's not possible for someone to be mistaken or to lie, you can probably prove the actual base claim ("climate change is real") a lot easier, and without having to involve any pesky psychology.

                                                          Edited by Sebastian Lamerichs on Sep 8, 2018 at 6:18
                                                          •
                                                            Simon Jones

                                                            Simon Jones

                                                            Sep 8, 2018 Sep 8, 2018 at 17:31
                                                            Well the premise is specifically for global warming, not climate change, and also that it’s tied in with human activity. Personally I’d dispute whether human activity is the cause of it (contributing factor or accelerator for the process, sure, but as a species compared to the history and cycles of the planet, we are insignificant, and more than a little misguided that everything is related to us). I would much rather see conversations about how to cope or adapt to climate change, rather than the misguided notion that humans can outright prevent it.
                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                            • Go To Parent

                                                            Well the premise is specifically for global warming, not climate change, and also that it’s tied in with human activity. Personally I’d dispute whether human activity is the cause of it (contributing factor or accelerator for the process, sure, but as a species compared to the history and cycles of the planet, we are insignificant, and more than a little misguided that everything is related to us). I would much rather see conversations about how to cope or adapt to climate change, rather than the misguided notion that humans can outright prevent it.

                                                          •
                                                            Nick Paputzoglu

                                                            Nick Paputzoglu

                                                            Sep 16, 2018 Sep 16, 2018 at 23:10
                                                            Ad Hominem: This is a tough one. You may also argue that the claim made by Person Y can be judged on whether it is true or reasonable if it can be directly correlated/linked with the character of the individual or their motives. For example, if Person Y has lied to Person X on multiple occasions, and now Person X doesn't like Person Y. Person Y has been judged to have a flaw in their character. As a result, there is a high probability Person Y would lie again. Hence, a claim Person Y makes to Person X, in the future, is more than likely not to be true or reasonable. Another example could be a politician who is an advocate against global warming. If the politician has received funding or donations from companies who emit high greenhouse emissions, then the politician more than likely has a motive in what they they claim to be true or reasonable, as a direct result of their affiliations. The politician's affiliations may be the reason why Person X does not like the politician and doesn't believe what they say can be true or reasonable. It seems it could be quite probable that Ad Hominem reasoning in not always fallacious.
                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                            • Go To Parent

                                                            Ad Hominem:

                                                            This is a tough one. You may also argue that the claim made by Person Y can be judged on whether it is true or reasonable if it can be directly correlated/linked with the character of the individual or their motives.

                                                            For example, if Person Y has lied to Person X on multiple occasions, and now Person X doesn't like Person Y. Person Y has been judged to have a flaw in their character. As a result, there is a high probability Person Y would lie again. Hence, a claim Person Y makes to Person X, in the future, is more than likely not to be true or reasonable.

                                                            Another example could be a politician who is an advocate against global warming. If the politician has received funding or donations from companies who emit high greenhouse emissions, then the politician more than likely has a motive in what they they claim to be true or reasonable, as a direct result of their affiliations. The politician's affiliations may be the reason why Person X does not like the politician and doesn't believe what they say can be true or reasonable.

                                                            It seems it could be quite probable that Ad Hominem reasoning in not always fallacious.

                                                            •
                                                              Erin Carroll

                                                              Erin Carroll

                                                              Sep 16, 2018 Sep 16, 2018 at 23:43
                                                              In regards to your global warming example, I am also not sure what Person 2's fallacy is in general, but often I think these types of responses are ad hominem arguments in disguise. E.g. "oh I don't like [political figure, etc, who's stating this argument about global warming] so uhm...I've never been so cold! Global warming isn't happening!"
                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                              • Go To Parent

                                                              In regards to your global warming example, I am also not sure what Person 2's fallacy is in general, but often I think these types of responses are ad hominem arguments in disguise. E.g. "oh I don't like [political figure, etc, who's stating this argument about global warming] so uhm...I've never been so cold! Global warming isn't happening!"

                                                                Collapse Subdiscussion Shyam Nath

                                                                Shyam Nath

                                                                Sep 18, 2018 Sep 18, 2018 at 8:11
                                                                🖖 Hello Mark,   Person 1s' global warming argument is appeal to authority (human error), and normative bandwagoning; consensus is within the interval (50%,100%].   NASA spaceships have exploded, killing all aboard, when a minority of authorities expressed ignored warnings; these events could be avoided by use of critical reasoning skills, since some employees will do any"-thing" to produce results sooner, rather than later ∵ it makes them look good for their next promotion, which they also want sooner, rather than later; even if these decisions could cost them their careers, since they'ren't using critical reasoning skills in their assessment of risk versus reward (desperate times call for desperate measures; using the apparent state of the economy as an apology for desperation, even though they are employed, and aren't tholing penury).   LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,AGENT S.🕴Migrating Infestive Bugs !!
                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                • Go To Parent
                                                                🖖 Hello Mark,
                                                                 
                                                                Person 1s' global warming argument is appeal to authority (human error), and normative bandwagoning; consensus is within the interval (50%,100%].
                                                                 
                                                                NASA spaceshipsLinks to an external site. have exploded, killing all aboard, when a minority of authorities expressed ignored warnings; these events could be avoided by use of critical reasoning skills, since some employees will do any"-thing" to produce results sooner, rather than later ∵ it makes them look good for their next promotion, which they also want sooner, rather than later; even if these decisions could cost them their careers, since they'ren't using critical reasoning skills in their assessment of risk versus reward (desperate times call for desperate measures; using the apparent state of the economy as an apology for desperation, even though they are employed, and aren't tholing penury).
                                                                 

                                                                LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
                                                                AGENT S.
                                                                🕴
                                                                Migrating Infestive Bugs !!

                                                                  PS: If there're only 10 authorities in a field, and 9 of them consent; that's a 90% majority, so I don't think percentages are very descriptive ∵ they can be deceptively misleading.

                                                                  PS: If there're only 10 authorities in a field, and 9 of them consent; that's a 90% majority, so I don't think percentages are very descriptive ∵ they can be deceptively misleading.

                                                                    PSS: I think the same of so-called "big data".

                                                                Collapse Subdiscussion Rhys Flemming

                                                                Rhys Flemming

                                                                Sep 4, 2018 Sep 4, 2018 at 14:13
                                                                I saw a Fallacious Argument in the textbook today which I felt was particularly relevant to Assignment 1 regarding privacy on the internet. PREMISE. The Internet is in public space.CONCLUSION. Those who use the Internet should not expect to retain any personal privacy As the essay we're required to write discusses the need for encryption in instant messaging applications, let's attempt to create a sound argument out of this example to the best we can. The textbook provides the example that a backpack in a public place would similarly be afforded personal privacy. Therefore, we can argue:COUNTER-PREMISE 1. Sections of and software within the internet are designed with the expectation of private interaction between two users.CONCLUSION. Those who use the Internet should expect to retain personal privacyNaturally, this would come with the caveat that this personal privacy would only exist in certain parts of the internet to different degrees but I feel like this is a sound argument because it is indisputable that the intention of the design in these platforms is to create a private space for users. Returning to the initial argument, let's consider the following:PREMISE 1. The Internet is in public space.PREMISE 2. Data shared in assumed private spaces are accessible to the owners of such platforms.PREMISE 3. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 permits ASIO to intercept telecommunications under warrant for intelligence gatheringCONCLUSION. Those who use the Internet should not expect to retain any personal privacy As I type this, I realise how much easier it is to create a sound argument for the expectation of privacy, the reason being that we would have to argue that there is absolutely no expectation of privacy across the entire internet where the counter-argument only needs to justify that there need only be personal privacy sometimes. Even my reinforced argument is fallible for instances of lawful users of the internet. Is there a way to create a sound argument for the above example? Maybe not. If you think you could, how would it be done?
                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                • Go To Topic

                                                                I saw a Fallacious Argument in the textbook today which I felt was particularly relevant to Assignment 1 regarding privacy on the internet.

                                                                PREMISE. The Internet is in public space.
                                                                CONCLUSION. Those who use the Internet should not expect to retain any personal privacy

                                                                As the essay we're required to write discusses the need for encryption in instant messaging applications, let's attempt to create a sound argument out of this example to the best we can.

                                                                The textbook provides the example that a backpack in a public place would similarly be afforded personal privacy. Therefore, we can argue:
                                                                COUNTER-PREMISE 1. Sections of and software within the internet are designed with the expectation of private interaction between two users.
                                                                CONCLUSION. Those who use the Internet should expect to retain personal privacy
                                                                Naturally, this would come with the caveat that this personal privacy would only exist in certain parts of the internet to different degrees but I feel like this is a sound argument because it is indisputable that the intention of the design in these platforms is to create a private space for users.

                                                                Returning to the initial argument, let's consider the following:
                                                                PREMISE 1. The Internet is in public space.
                                                                PREMISE 2. Data shared in assumed private spaces are accessible to the owners of such platforms.
                                                                PREMISE 3. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 permits ASIO to intercept telecommunications under warrant for intelligence gathering
                                                                CONCLUSION. Those who use the Internet should not expect to retain any personal privacy

                                                                As I type this, I realise how much easier it is to create a sound argument for the expectation of privacy, the reason being that we would have to argue that there is absolutely no expectation of privacy across the entire internet where the counter-argument only needs to justify that there need only be personal privacy sometimes. Even my reinforced argument is fallible for instances of lawful users of the internet.

                                                                Is there a way to create a sound argument for the above example? Maybe not. If you think you could, how would it be done?

                                                                •
                                                                  Collapse Subdiscussion Simon Jones

                                                                  Simon Jones

                                                                  Sep 7, 2018 Sep 7, 2018 at 1:27
                                                                  From the course material, "Relatively few valid arguments are sound. Relatively few sound arguments are informative or non-trivial."
                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                  • Go To Parent

                                                                  From the course material, "Relatively few valid arguments are sound. Relatively few sound arguments are informative or non-trivial."

P(1): Servers are private property. C(0)∴ Internet's not in public space.   Backpacks in a public place can be stolen/looted/ETC, and security is never guaranteed under any circumstances; data breaches, compromised servers, malicious server owners/staff, ETC.   LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,AGENT S.🕴Migrating Infestive Bugs !!

                                                                    C(0)∴ Internet's not in public space.

                                                                    Collapse Subdiscussion Joshua Whaanga

                                                                    Joshua Whaanga

                                                                    Sep 4, 2018 Sep 4, 2018 at 22:17
                                                                    In regards to activity 2, is it safe to say that there can be more than one answer? i found getting a couple of fallacies in some of argument eg. A politician degrading another politician during a political campaign when asked about a specific policy – “Well, I think we need to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic.”  I thought it was both Ad Hominem or straw man
                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                    • Go To Topic

                                                                    In regards to activity 2, is it safe to say that there can be more than one answer? i found getting a couple of fallacies in some of argument

                                                                    eg.

                                                                    A politician degrading another politician during a political campaign when asked about a specific policy – “Well, I think we need to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic.” 

                                                                    I thought it was both Ad Hominem or straw man

                                                                    •
                                                                      Collapse Subdiscussion Paola Gonzalez Aguero

                                                                      Paola Gonzalez Aguero

                                                                      Sep 5, 2018 Sep 5, 2018 at 12:43
                                                                      I think this falls mostly (if not entirely) under Ad Hominem, just because nothing specific about what the other candidate said/supports is actually being mentioned. From what I understand, straw man is when you take someone's opinion/words and misrepresent them so that they are easier to "defeat" (in the argument).  Random example from the Internet about straw man: "Caroline says that she thinks her friends should not be so rude to the new girl. Jenna says that she cannot believe that Caroline is choosing to be better friends with the new girl than the girls who have always known her." (which is obviously not what Caroline meant) Ad Hominem is more focused on weakening someone's argument by attacking their character (in this case, the politician's "failures?"). At least that's what I think.
                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                      • Go To Parent

                                                                      I think this falls mostly (if not entirely) under Ad Hominem, just because nothing specific about what the other candidate said/supports is actually being mentioned. From what I understand, straw man is when you take someone's opinion/words and misrepresent them so that they are easier to "defeat" (in the argument). 

                                                                      Random example from the Internet about straw man:

                                                                      "Caroline says that she thinks her friends should not be so rude to the new girl. Jenna says that she cannot believe that Caroline is choosing to be better friends with the new girl than the girls who have always known her." (which is obviously not what Caroline meant)

                                                                      Ad Hominem is more focused on weakening someone's argument by attacking their character (in this case, the politician's "failures?").

                                                                      At least that's what I think.

                                                                        Hi Joshua,   I also agree that the argument falls into Ad Hominem where the candidates are attacking another candidates.   Straw man fallacy occurs when A politician restates statement from another politician with distorted way. But the argument in activity 2 has not mentioned anything about restate.     Cheers,   Ricky

                                                                        Collapse Subdiscussion Simon Jones

                                                                        Simon Jones

                                                                        Sep 7, 2018 Sep 7, 2018 at 0:36
                                                                        Week 1 – Activity 1 Premise 1: Downloading proprietary software (without permission from the copyright holder) is identical to stealing physical property. Premise 2: Stealing physical property is morally wrong. Conclusion: Therefore, downloading proprietary software (without permission) is morally wrong. Valid, but unsound. I’d almost argue inconclusive as well, as morality can’t really be verified, and varies wildly between individuals and cultures. I also don’t agree that downloading proprietary software is directly comparable to stealing physical property. It certainly can inflict some form of harm to an individual, but downloading a pirated version of Windows is not the same as stealing someone’s crutches when they have a broken ankle. Harm can certainly occur and the owner does suffer a loss, but it’s more indirect.   Example 1 Premise 1: All trees are plants. Premise 2: The redwood is a tree. Conclusion: Therefore, redwood is a plant. Valid and sound. Although you could argue semantics. “The redwood” could be interpreted as a singular entity, and “redwood is a plant”. Well yes, the tree itself is. But the resulting item if used in say, a log cabin, is a type of wood…it’s certainly derived from a plant as a product, but you wouldn’t say it’s a plant.   Example 2 Premise 1: All basketballs are round. Premise 2: The Earth is round. Conclusion: Therefore, the Earth is a basketball. Invalid and fallacious. For starters, the Earth is not round (unless you’re in pre-school and haven’t learnt about more complex shapes) , and there’s nothing really linking the two premises beyond a geometric shape. Red herring maybe?   Example 3 Premise 1: All GPS satellites are positioned underwater. Premise 2: Everything positioned underwater becomes wet. Conclusion: Therefore, GPS satellites are wet. Valid, but unsound. The premises might very well be stupid, but have to be assumed true. Clearly GPS satellites aren’t positioned underwater (although parts of it might end up in the ocean at the end of their orbit), and submariners are positioned underwater without getting wet (sure the submarine itself does, but not what’s inside it). Again, red herring?   Example 4 Premise 1: Beckham is famous. Premise 2: Beckham is a football player. Conclusion: Therefore, Beckham is a famous football player. Invalid and fallacious. Can’t even pretend to care about arguing this one further. False dichotomy?   Example 5 Premise 1: Some of the computer programmers play piano. Premise 2: No one who plays piano watches footy matches. Conclusion: Some computer programmers watch footy matches. Invalid and fallacious. False dichotomy? Again, sports, no interest in discussing this one.   Week 1 – Activity 2 Argument: John is a con artist. John has black hair. Therefore, all people with black hair are con artists. Fallacy: False Cause   Argument: A politician degrading another politician during a political campaign when asked about a specific policy – “Well, I think we need to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic.” Fallacy: Ad Hominem   Argument: There is a lot of commotion regarding saving the environment. We cannot make this world an Eden. What will happen if it does become Eden? Adam and Eve got bored there! Fallacy: Red herring? Could argue False Cause as well.   Argument: Child to parent: Either you buy me this new book, or you decide that reading is not important at all. Fallacy: False Dichotomy   Argument: If we allow the children to choose the movie this time, they are going to expect to be able to choose the school they go to or the doctors they visit. Fallacy: Slippery Slope   Week 1 – Activity 3 What is the role of Thesis statement in the introduction of an essay/paper? Provide a summary of the overall essay, of what the essay itself is trying to achieve or convince the reader of.   What is a Topic sentence for a paragraph? It determines the intent or focus of the paragraph, setting up the rest of the paragraph to be in support of the topic itself.   What is an argument? How is it structured? Arguments are a set of claims to try and convince others of your reasoning or point of view. It consists of one or more premises, and a conclusion.   What are assumptions? Statements to help eliminate any potential ambiguity, or to define the scope of what is being considered, and what is not. What are the assumptions of the following arguments? In 2008, the President of the USA promised to prevent the country entering economic depression, but he failed because at the beginning of 2012, over 12 million USA citizens were unemployed. The assumption is that the USA is in an economic depression, and that the same President responsible is still in power.   Chilean students were right in 2012 to stage protests demanding that university education in Chile should be made free. The assumption is that they were successful…at least by some kind of metric.
                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                        • Go To Topic

                                                                        Week 1 – Activity 1

                                                                        Premise 1: Downloading proprietary software (without permission from the copyright holder) is identical to stealing physical property.

                                                                        Premise 2: Stealing physical property is morally wrong.

                                                                        Conclusion: Therefore, downloading proprietary software (without permission) is morally wrong.

                                                                        Valid, but unsound. I’d almost argue inconclusive as well, as morality can’t really be verified, and varies wildly between individuals and cultures. I also don’t agree that downloading proprietary software is directly comparable to stealing physical property. It certainly can inflict some form of harm to an individual, but downloading a pirated version of Windows is not the same as stealing someone’s crutches when they have a broken ankle. Harm can certainly occur and the owner does suffer a loss, but it’s more indirect.

                                                                         

                                                                        Example 1

                                                                        Premise 1: All trees are plants.

                                                                        Premise 2: The redwood is a tree.

                                                                        Conclusion: Therefore, redwood is a plant.

                                                                        Valid and sound. Although you could argue semantics. “The redwood” could be interpreted as a singular entity, and “redwood is a plant”. Well yes, the tree itself is. But the resulting item if used in say, a log cabin, is a type of wood…it’s certainly derived from a plant as a product, but you wouldn’t say it’s a plant.

                                                                         

                                                                        Example 2

                                                                        Premise 1: All basketballs are round.

                                                                        Premise 2: The Earth is round.

                                                                        Conclusion: Therefore, the Earth is a basketball.

                                                                        Invalid and fallacious. For starters, the Earth is not round (unless you’re in pre-school and haven’t learnt about more complex shapes) , and there’s nothing really linking the two premises beyond a geometric shape. Red herring maybe?

                                                                         

                                                                        Example 3

                                                                        Premise 1: All GPS satellites are positioned underwater.

                                                                        Premise 2: Everything positioned underwater becomes wet.

                                                                        Conclusion: Therefore, GPS satellites are wet.

                                                                        Valid, but unsound. The premises might very well be stupid, but have to be assumed true. Clearly GPS satellites aren’t positioned underwater (although parts of it might end up in the ocean at the end of their orbit), and submariners are positioned underwater without getting wet (sure the submarine itself does, but not what’s inside it). Again, red herring?

                                                                         

                                                                        Example 4

                                                                        Premise 1: Beckham is famous.

                                                                        Premise 2: Beckham is a football player.

                                                                        Conclusion: Therefore, Beckham is a famous football player.

                                                                        Invalid and fallacious. Can’t even pretend to care about arguing this one further. False dichotomy?

                                                                         

                                                                        Example 5

                                                                        Premise 1: Some of the computer programmers play piano.

                                                                        Premise 2: No one who plays piano watches footy matches.

                                                                        Conclusion: Some computer programmers watch footy matches.

                                                                        Invalid and fallacious. False dichotomy? Again, sports, no interest in discussing this one.

                                                                         

                                                                        Week 1 – Activity 2

                                                                        Argument: John is a con artist. John has black hair. Therefore, all people with black hair are con artists.

                                                                        Fallacy: False Cause

                                                                         

                                                                        Argument: A politician degrading another politician during a political campaign when asked about a specific policy – “Well, I think we need to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic.”

                                                                        Fallacy: Ad Hominem

                                                                         

                                                                        Argument: There is a lot of commotion regarding saving the environment. We cannot make this world an Eden. What will happen if it does become Eden? Adam and Eve got bored there!

                                                                        Fallacy: Red herring? Could argue False Cause as well.

                                                                         

                                                                        Argument: Child to parent: Either you buy me this new book, or you decide that reading is not important at all.

                                                                        Fallacy: False Dichotomy

                                                                         

                                                                        Argument: If we allow the children to choose the movie this time, they are going to expect to be able to choose the school they go to or the doctors they visit.

                                                                        Fallacy: Slippery Slope

                                                                         

                                                                        Week 1 – Activity 3

                                                                        1. What is the role of Thesis statement in the introduction of an essay/paper?

                                                                        Provide a summary of the overall essay, of what the essay itself is trying to achieve or convince the reader of.

                                                                         

                                                                        1. What is a Topic sentence for a paragraph?

                                                                        It determines the intent or focus of the paragraph, setting up the rest of the paragraph to be in support of the topic itself.

                                                                         

                                                                        1. What is an argument? How is it structured?

                                                                        Arguments are a set of claims to try and convince others of your reasoning or point of view. It consists of one or more premises, and a conclusion.

                                                                         

                                                                        1. What are assumptions?

                                                                        Statements to help eliminate any potential ambiguity, or to define the scope of what is being considered, and what is not.

                                                                        1. What are the assumptions of the following arguments?
                                                                        2. In 2008, the President of the USA promised to prevent the country entering economic depression, but he failed because at the beginning of 2012, over 12 million USA citizens were unemployed.

                                                                        The assumption is that the USA is in an economic depression, and that the same President responsible is still in power.

                                                                         

                                                                        1. Chilean students were right in 2012 to stage protests demanding that university education in Chile should be made free.

                                                                        The assumption is that they were successful…at least by some kind of metric.

                                                                        •

                                                                          Sep 17, 2018 Sep 17, 2018 at 9:33
                                                                          🖖 Hello Simon,   Example 2 Earth is round ∵ if you zoom in on a curve, it becomes a straight/flat ∴ a curve is either curved, straight/flat, or both.   LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,AGENT S.🕴Migrating Infestive Bugs !!
                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                          • Go To Parent
                                                                          🖖 Hello Simon,
                                                                           
                                                                          Example 2
                                                                          Earth is round ∵ if you zoom in on a curve, it becomes a straight/flat ∴ a curve is either curved, straight/flat, or both.

                                                                          AGENT S.

                                                                          Collapse Subdiscussion Benjamin O'Brien

                                                                          Benjamin O'Brien

                                                                          Sep 9, 2018 Sep 9, 2018 at 13:26
                                                                          I have been thinking about question 5 in the tutorial from week 1 after watching the recorded session this week. With regards to assumptions I think 5a has plenty of assumptions, for example around what level of unemployment constitutes economic depression and whether 12 million is a significant number of unemployed persons, however I don't think 5b has many assumptions. Chilean students were right in 2012 to stage protests demanding that university education in Chile should be made free. From my perspective there are no significant assumptions here. In response to the answers posted in the recording: A1: Education is free in some other parts of the world - I believe the argument remains valid whether or not this is the case. If no other country had free education it could still be argued that it should be provided and these students in Chile are arguing for this in their country first. A2: Staging protests is going to change the policy - The argument does not rely on the premise that the protests will change anything, it's conclusion is that the students were right to stage protests, whether or not they are effective or not. A3: Most students in Chile want to attend university - I believe the argument remains just as valid whether most students want to attend university or not. If you believe that the country would be better off with free education, whether or not 10% or 90% of the population want to attend, it is still right to demand free education. For example, if you were a tradesperson (assuming this did not require a university education) you may not wish to attend university, however, you would want the doctors, engineers and lawmakers that serve yourself and your community to have an affordable education. A4: University education is not free in Chile - Assuming that there were in fact protests in Chile in 2012 this is not an assumption. If the protests occurred then education must not be free. If I were to say that there were any assumptions in this argument I would potentially say the assumption that protests were staged in 2012 could be considered, however this is more of a fact. More relevantly, you could propose that the definition of "right" is an assumption, however that could become a very esoteric debate. Interested if anyone has any other thoughts?
                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                          • Go To Topic

                                                                          I have been thinking about question 5 in the tutorial from week 1 after watching the recorded session this week.

                                                                          With regards to assumptions I think 5a has plenty of assumptions, for example around what level of unemployment constitutes economic depression and whether 12 million is a significant number of unemployed persons, however I don't think 5b has many assumptions.

                                                                          Chilean students were right in 2012 to stage protests demanding that university education in Chile should be made free.

                                                                          From my perspective there are no significant assumptions here. In response to the answers posted in the recording:

                                                                          A1: Education is free in some other parts of the world - I believe the argument remains valid whether or not this is the case. If no other country had free education it could still be argued that it should be provided and these students in Chile are arguing for this in their country first.

                                                                          A2: Staging protests is going to change the policy - The argument does not rely on the premise that the protests will change anything, it's conclusion is that the students were right to stage protests, whether or not they are effective or not.

                                                                          A3: Most students in Chile want to attend university - I believe the argument remains just as valid whether most students want to attend university or not. If you believe that the country would be better off with free education, whether or not 10% or 90% of the population want to attend, it is still right to demand free education. For example, if you were a tradesperson (assuming this did not require a university education) you may not wish to attend university, however, you would want the doctors, engineers and lawmakers that serve yourself and your community to have an affordable education.

                                                                          A4: University education is not free in Chile - Assuming that there were in fact protests in Chile in 2012 this is not an assumption. If the protests occurred then education must not be free.

                                                                          If I were to say that there were any assumptions in this argument I would potentially say the assumption that protests were staged in 2012 could be considered, however this is more of a fact. More relevantly, you could propose that the definition of "right" is an assumption, however that could become a very esoteric debate.

                                                                          Interested if anyone has any other thoughts?

                                                                          •
                                                                            Scott Feeney

                                                                            Scott Feeney

                                                                            Sep 15, 2018 Sep 15, 2018 at 16:42
                                                                            Benjamin, I was part of the live tutorial/discussion group and this particular part of the tutorial was the one that I felt had the most room for interpretation too.  Here are my thoughts: Argument: Chilean students were right in 2012 to stage protests demanding thatuniversity education in Chile should be made free. Assumption 1: People (in this case the students) are right to protest.  If we compare this protest to those that protest outside abortion clinics, are those people right?  It is a tricky one I know, and depends very much on where you stand on the topic, but is it right to protest?  Is it right to protest when hate groups have rallys? Is it right to protest when Phil Collins announces that he's coming back? Assumption 2: People (in this case the students) have the right to protest. The first assumption was around is it right or just to protest.  The second assumption, in my opinion is from a legal point of view; do they have the legal right?  Is protesting legal in Chile?  I know in some countries protesting is not legal. I can only guess that protesting in North Korea would be met with understanding and consideration, or not. Assumption 3: Protesting is a guaranteed way to change government policy. Does the government, or whoever decides university fees in Chile, listen to protest or do they have a strict anti-change from protest policy, similar to how you hear (in movies) how the US Government does not negotiate with terrorists (it's a long bow, I know). Assumption 4: University education is Chile costs money. We can assume that it does, otherwise a protest to make it free seems a bit silly, but it was not explicitly stated that it does cost money to attend university in Chile. Anyway...these are my thoughts.  A few were along similar lines to you, but a few were along different lines, for example the "justness" of protesting. Cheers, Scott
                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                            • Go To Parent

                                                                            Benjamin,

                                                                            I was part of the live tutorial/discussion group and this particular part of the tutorial was the one that I felt had the most room for interpretation too.  Here are my thoughts:

                                                                            Argument:

                                                                            Chilean students were right in 2012 to stage protests demanding that
                                                                            university education in Chile should be made free.

                                                                            Assumption 1:

                                                                            People (in this case the students) are right to protest. 

                                                                            If we compare this protest to those that protest outside abortion clinics, are those people right?  It is a tricky one I know, and depends very much on where you stand on the topic, but is it right to protest?  Is it right to protest when hate groups have rallys? Is it right to protest when Phil Collins announces that he's coming back?

                                                                            Assumption 2:

                                                                            People (in this case the students) have the right to protest.

                                                                            The first assumption was around is it right or just to protest.  The second assumption, in my opinion is from a legal point of view; do they have the legal right?  Is protesting legal in Chile?  I know in some countries protesting is not legal. I can only guess that protesting in North Korea would be met with understanding and consideration, or not.

                                                                            Assumption 3:

                                                                            Protesting is a guaranteed way to change government policy.

                                                                            Does the government, or whoever decides university fees in Chile, listen to protest or do they have a strict anti-change from protest policy, similar to how you hear (in movies) how the US Government does not negotiate with terrorists (it's a long bow, I know).

                                                                            Assumption 4:

                                                                            University education is Chile costs money.

                                                                            We can assume that it does, otherwise a protest to make it free seems a bit silly, but it was not explicitly stated that it does cost money to attend university in Chile.

                                                                            Anyway...these are my thoughts.  A few were along similar lines to you, but a few were along different lines, for example the "justness" of protesting.

                                                                            Cheers,

                                                                            Scott

                                                                            •
                                                                              Shyam Nath

                                                                              Shyam Nath

                                                                              Sep 17, 2018 Sep 17, 2018 at 9:15
                                                                              🖖 Hello Benjamin, and Scott,   It could also be interpreted as; they were "right in 2012" to stage the protests.   But it's more normative to interpret it as; they were right, as in it was a good decision; as opposed to, they were in the right, or had right of way.   It could either be; being right about staging protests to make demands, being right that university education should be free, or both.   We cannot assume they are right about protesting, since lobbying is the right alternative.   Since free education is paid for by the tax payers; whether, or not, they are right to protest for it is an assumption.   LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,AGENT S.🕴Migrating Infestive Bugs !!
                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                              • Go To Parent
                                                                              🖖 Hello Benjamin, and Scott,
                                                                               
                                                                              It could also be interpreted as; they were "right in 2012" to stage the protests.
                                                                               
                                                                              But it's more normative to interpret it as; they were right, as in it was a good decision; as opposed to, they were in the right, or had right of way.
                                                                               
                                                                              It could either be; being right about staging protests to make demands, being right that university education should be free, or both.
                                                                               
                                                                              We cannot assume they are right about protesting, since lobbying is the right alternative.
                                                                               
                                                                              Since free education is paid for by the tax payers; whether, or not, they are right to protest for it is an assumption.
                                                                               

                                                                              LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
                                                                              AGENT S.
