                                                                                Benjamin Whitbread

                                                                                Benjamin Whitbread

                                                                                Sep 11, 2018 Sep 11, 2018 at 3:34
                                                                                I was a bit confused by the difference between Composition and Guilt By association but I think I understand now, Fallacy of Composition being the attribution of characteristics particular to one part of the whole to the whole itself eg. The Snowy Mountains are cold, therefore all of Australia is cold or The atoms that make me are incredibly small, therefore I am incredibly small Whereas Guilt By Association asserts that that two (or more) things share certain properties, therefore they must be the same such as in the tute questions "John is a con artist. John has black hair. Therefore, all people with black hair are con artists". I think the trouble I had stemmed from reading the wording of "parts of a whole" too broadly.
                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                • Go To Topic

                                                                                I was a bit confused by the difference between Composition and Guilt By association but I think I understand now,

                                                                                Fallacy of Composition being the attribution of characteristics particular to one part of the whole to the whole itself eg. The Snowy Mountains are cold, therefore all of Australia is cold or The atoms that make me are incredibly small, therefore I am incredibly small

                                                                                Whereas Guilt By Association asserts that that two (or more) things share certain properties, therefore they must be the same such as in the tute questions "John is a con artist. John has black hair. Therefore, all people with black hair are con artists".

                                                                                I think the trouble I had stemmed from reading the wording of "parts of a whole" too broadly.

                                                                                •

                                                                                  Elizabeth Tulino

                                                                                  Sep 11, 2018 Sep 11, 2018 at 3:46
                                                                                  Hi all, I only graduated high school in 2011; however, I felt relatively "out of touch" with the critical thinking skills for week one. There was an emphasis placed on them during high school but I haven't really encountered them since in the workplace or in my further education. Going back to the "roots" of it and relearning what a thesis statement, topic sentence etc was enlightening as I think I had an 80% grasp was helpful but there were certain aspects I definitely needed the re-up. Did anyone else find this? Not necessarily wrong in your thoughts, but you've deviated from the original definitions? I had thought that a topic sentence needed to tie the topic in with the previous paragraph... Cheers, Liz
                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                  • Go To Topic

                                                                                  Hi all,

                                                                                  I only graduated high school in 2011; however, I felt relatively "out of touch" with the critical thinking skills for week one. There was an emphasis placed on them during high school but I haven't really encountered them since in the workplace or in my further education.

                                                                                  Going back to the "roots" of it and relearning what a thesis statement, topic sentence etc was enlightening as I think I had an 80% grasp was helpful but there were certain aspects I definitely needed the re-up.

                                                                                  Did anyone else find this? Not necessarily wrong in your thoughts, but you've deviated from the original definitions? I had thought that a topic sentence needed to tie the topic in with the previous paragraph...

                                                                                  Cheers,

                                                                                  Liz

                                                                                    Collapse Subdiscussion Christopher Bowe

                                                                                    Christopher Bowe

                                                                                    Sep 13, 2018 Sep 13, 2018 at 22:38
                                                                                    I agree that i haven't personally encountered the need for the critical thinking skills explained in week 1 in the real world, specifically regarding the need to analyze an argument to study whether its a valid argument and if the  statements within it are true. I'm working full time at the moment and studying my degree to further my work opportunities and constantly thinking where i can apply my studies to work. Reading the first weeks study materials my first thoughts were if i turned up to work and started methodologically analyzing peoples arguments like this i'd be perceived as a bit of a robot! But obviously we're in the early weeks and even if I don't foresee myself using the exact methods we're being taught in the real world, i think perhaps being taught the concepts will maybe change the way i approach arguments. I did really enjoy learning about the common fallacies though as that was something new to me. Again thinking back to people i deal with in the workplace, and while i try not to make a habit of analyzing people, learning about the common fallacies it becomes pretty apparent there are people you'll encounter who constantly stick with the same fallacy type in a lot of their arguments.

                                                                                    I'm working full time at the moment and studying my degree to further my work opportunities and constantly thinking where i can apply my studies to work. Reading the first weeks study materials my first thoughts were if i turned up to work and started methodologically analyzing peoples arguments like this i'd be perceived as a bit of a robot! But obviously we're in the early weeks and even if I don't foresee myself using the exact methods we're being taught in the real world, i think perhaps being taught the concepts will maybe change the way i approach arguments.

                                                                                    I did really enjoy learning about the common fallacies though as that was something new to me. Again thinking back to people i deal with in the workplace, and while i try not to make a habit of analyzing people, learning about the common fallacies it becomes pretty apparent there are people you'll encounter who constantly stick with the same fallacy type in a lot of their arguments.

                                                                                    Collapse Subdiscussion Carly Ritchie

                                                                                    Carly Ritchie

                                                                                    Sep 12, 2018 Sep 12, 2018 at 18:00
                                                                                    Thought it might be fun exercise to create logical fallacies to enhance understanding. Logical fallacies illustrated by the question "Should I have a cookie?"   Ad Hominem: You just don't want me to have a cookie because you're a mean, terrible person and probably selfishly keeping all the cookies for yourself. Slippery Slope: It's never just one cookie. You'll have another, and another, until they're all gone and you're the size of house. Appeal to Authority: Even the Cookie Monster thinks that cookies are a 'sometimes' food. Health experts recommend a piece of fruit to satisfy your sweet tooth. False Cause: Last time you had a cookie you got the flu the next week. All that sugar is making you sick. Division: Cookies are full of butter, if you cut butter out of your diet you wouldn't want them anymore. Ambiguity: You really want to have a cookie? Fine, you can have the cookie, but you can't eat it. False Dichotomy: Do you want the cookie or do you want to live a long time and be healthy? Virtuality: ???   Okay, I'm stuck on the concept of virtual cookies. Anyone have suggestions?
                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                    • Go To Topic

                                                                                    Thought it might be fun exercise to create logical fallacies to enhance understanding. Logical fallacies illustrated by the question "Should I have a cookie?"

                                                                                     

                                                                                    Ad Hominem: You just don't want me to have a cookie because you're a mean, terrible person and probably selfishly keeping all the cookies for yourself.

                                                                                    Slippery Slope: It's never just one cookie. You'll have another, and another, until they're all gone and you're the size of house.

                                                                                    Appeal to Authority: Even the Cookie Monster thinks that cookies are a 'sometimes' food. Health experts recommend a piece of fruit to satisfy your sweet tooth.

                                                                                    False Cause: Last time you had a cookie you got the flu the next week. All that sugar is making you sick.

                                                                                    Division: Cookies are full of butter, if you cut butter out of your diet you wouldn't want them anymore.

                                                                                    Ambiguity: You really want to have a cookie? Fine, you can have the cookie, but you can't eat it.

                                                                                    False Dichotomy: Do you want the cookie or do you want to live a long time and be healthy?

                                                                                    Virtuality: ???

                                                                                     

                                                                                    Okay, I'm stuck on the concept of virtual cookies. Anyone have suggestions?

                                                                                    •
                                                                                      Scott Feeney

                                                                                      Scott Feeney

                                                                                      Sep 15, 2018 Sep 15, 2018 at 16:14
                                                                                      Virtuality: Cookies exist in cyberspace. Therefore, cookies are not real.  I may have underthought this 🤔. We do know that this is not correct...... Cookies are small files which are stored on a user's computer. They are designed to hold a modest amount of data specific to a particular client and website, and can be accessed either by the web server or the client computer. This allows the server to deliver a page tailored to a particular user, or the page itself can contain some script which is aware of the data in the cookie and so is able to carry information from one visit to the website (or related site) to the next. (http://www.whatarecookies.com/) Does the fact that they exist make it a fallacy?
                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                      • Go To Parent

                                                                                      Virtuality: Cookies exist in cyberspace. Therefore, cookies are not real. 

                                                                                      I may have underthought this 🤔.

                                                                                      We do know that this is not correct......

                                                                                      Cookies are small files which are stored on a user's computer. They are designed to hold a modest amount of data specific to a particular client and website, and can be accessed either by the web server or the client computer. This allows the server to deliver a page tailored to a particular user, or the page itself can contain some script which is aware of the data in the cookie and so is able to carry information from one visit to the website (or related site) to the next. (http://www.whatarecookies.com/Links to an external site.)

                                                                                      Does the fact that they exist make it a fallacy?

                                                                                        David Jewell

                                                                                        David Jewell

                                                                                        Sep 13, 2018 Sep 13, 2018 at 11:59
                                                                                        Some of my thought for the first two questions. Premise – Downloading proprietary software is identical to stealing physical property. Premise – Stealing physical property is morally wrong. Conclusion – Downloading software without permission is wrong. Valid but unsound. Reasoning – Downloading software is not identical to stealing physical property.  Stealing a car is an example of stealing physical property where if I downloaded a piece of software that you designed I have infringed upon copyright laws. Premise – All trees are plants Premise – The redwood is a tree Conclusion – Redwood is a plant. Valid and sound. Reasoning – Argument is valid, and both premises are true in the actual world. Premise – All basketballs are round. Premise – The Earth is round. Conclusion – The earth is a basketball. invalid argument and fallacious statement. Reasoning – The conclusion is false even with both premises being true. Premise – All GPS satellites are positioned underwater. Premise – Everything positioned underwater becomes wet. Conclusion – GPS satellites are wet. Valid but unsound with false premises. Reasoning – Argument is true if both premises are assumed true but one premise is false. Premise – Beckham is famous Premise – Beckham is a football player Conclusion – Beckham is a famous football player. Sound argument. Reasoning – Both premises true in the real world. Premise – Some of the computer programmers play piano Premise – No one who plays piano watches football matches Conclusion – Some computer programmers watch footy matches. Invalid argument and fallacious with false premises. Reasoning – Even assuming both premises are true the conclusion would be false. Classify statements Argument 1 – Guilty by association.  Hair colour doesn’t make someone a con artist. Argument 2 – Ad hominem – focusing on candidate rather than argument. Argument 3 – Post hoc false cause – Adam and eve got bored in Eden so if we create Eden we will get bored. Argument 4 – False dilemma – Trying to make an argument out of mutually exclusive opinions. Argument 5 – Slippery slope – Giving the children choice could possibly be abused therefore we won’t give them any choice.
                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                        • Go To Topic

                                                                                        Some of my thought for the first two questions.

                                                                                        Premise – Downloading proprietary software is identical to stealing physical property.

                                                                                        Premise – Stealing physical property is morally wrong.

                                                                                        Conclusion – Downloading software without permission is wrong.

                                                                                        Valid but unsound.

                                                                                        Reasoning – Downloading software is not identical to stealing physical property.  Stealing a car is an example of stealing physical property where if I downloaded a piece of software that you designed I have infringed upon copyright laws.

                                                                                        Premise – All trees are plants

                                                                                        Premise – The redwood is a tree

                                                                                        Conclusion – Redwood is a plant.

                                                                                        Valid and sound.

                                                                                        Reasoning – Argument is valid, and both premises are true in the actual world.

                                                                                        Premise – All basketballs are round.

                                                                                        Premise – The Earth is round.

                                                                                        Conclusion – The earth is a basketball.

                                                                                        invalid argument and fallacious statement.

                                                                                        Reasoning – The conclusion is false even with both premises being true.

                                                                                        Premise – All GPS satellites are positioned underwater.

                                                                                        Premise – Everything positioned underwater becomes wet.

                                                                                        Conclusion – GPS satellites are wet.

                                                                                        Valid but unsound with false premises.

                                                                                        Reasoning – Argument is true if both premises are assumed true but one premise is false.

                                                                                        Premise – Beckham is famous

                                                                                        Premise – Beckham is a football player

                                                                                        Conclusion – Beckham is a famous football player.

                                                                                        Sound argument.

                                                                                        Reasoning – Both premises true in the real world.

                                                                                        Premise – Some of the computer programmers play piano

                                                                                        Premise – No one who plays piano watches football matches

                                                                                        Conclusion – Some computer programmers watch footy matches.

                                                                                        Invalid argument and fallacious with false premises.

                                                                                        Reasoning – Even assuming both premises are true the conclusion would be false.

                                                                                        Classify statements

                                                                                        Argument 1 – Guilty by association.  Hair colour doesn’t make someone a con artist.

                                                                                        Argument 2 – Ad hominem – focusing on candidate rather than argument.

                                                                                        Argument 3 – Post hoc false cause – Adam and eve got bored in Eden so if we create Eden we will get bored.

                                                                                        Argument 4 – False dilemma – Trying to make an argument out of mutually exclusive opinions.

                                                                                        Argument 5 – Slippery slope – Giving the children choice could possibly be abused therefore we won’t give them any choice.

                                                                                          Collapse Subdiscussion Monica Abau-Sapulai

                                                                                          Monica Abau-Sapulai

                                                                                          Sep 13, 2018 Sep 13, 2018 at 13:02
                                                                                          WEEK 1 – TUTORIAL QUESTIONS Activity One – Downloading Proprietary Software Downloading Proprietary Software (without permission from the Copyright Owner) is identical to stealing physical property. Stealing physical property is morally wrong. Therefore, downloading proprietary software (without permission) is morally wrong.   7 Step Strategy for Evaluating Arguments Step 1 – Convert into Standard form Premise 1 – Downloading Proprietary Software without permission is identical to stealing physical       property Premise 2 – Stealing physical property is morally wrong Conclusion - Downloading Proprietary Software without permission is morally wrong Step 2 – Test whether argument is Valid or Invalid               Argument is valid, there is no counterexample Step 3 – Is the argument valid ? Yes Step 4 – Is the valid argument Sound? Yes, all Premises are true in the actual world Step 5 – Is the invalid argument inductive or fallacious – Not applicable Step 6 – The premises are true in the actual world Step 7 – Overall Assesment Copyright is 100% automatically assumed by the Creator / Owner. Any use other works without the owners permission is morally wrong Downloading copyrighted software is equivalent to stealing physical property. Stealing is morally wrong The arguments overall strength is sound, valid and inductive with true premises. Activity Two – Classify the Given Statements Argument Fallacy Name John is a con artist. John has black hair. Therefore, all people with black hair are con artists. Composition   A politician degrading another politician during a political campaign when asked about a specific policy – “Well, I think we need to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic.” Ad Hominem There is a lot of commotion regarding saving the environment. We cannot make this world an Eden. What will happen if it does become Eden? Adam and Eve got bored there! False Dichotomy of False Dilema Child to parent: Either you buy me this new book, or you decide that reading is not important at all. Appeal to Authority If we allow the children to choose the movie this time, they are going to expect to be able to choose the school they go to or the doctors they visit. Slippery Slope     Activity Three - Define the following terms and explain their use   What is the role of the Thesis Statement in the introduction of an essay paper? The Thesis Statement in an essay is about figuring out the main idea for the essay and then explaining that to the reader in the paper. It outlines what the paper is about and helps the writer focus on the subject or argument of the paper. www.cws.illinois.edu/workshop/writers/tips/thesis/ What is a Topic Sentence for a paragraph? After the writer decides on their position in an argument, they write paragraphs to support their position and Topic Sentence is the sentence that contains the main idea that will be discussed in a paragraph. https://www.matrix.edu.au/how-to-write-a-topic-sentence/ What is an argument? How is it structured? An argument is the main idea that is to be discussed in an essay. It is the main idea or claim that must be justified with reasons. It consists of group of statements that support each other towards the conclusion. https://criticalthinkersworld.wordpress.com/the-basic-structure-of-argument/ What is an assumptions? When writing an essay and defending a position, the writer makes statements without trying to prove them, the writer simply assumes that those statements are true …these are assumptions https://app.shoreline.edu/doldham/101/HTML/Assumptions.htm   5. What are the assumptions of the following arguments?   The assumption is that the US President failed to deliver his promise of 2008 because over 12 million USA Citizens were unemployed in 2012. The writer does not attempt to provide evidence to prove that 12 million citizens were unemployed.   The assumption is that Chilean students were right to protest that Uni education should be free. The writer does not prove why their action to protest was right…        
                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                          • Go To Topic

                                                                                          WEEK 1 – TUTORIAL QUESTIONS

                                                                                          Activity One – Downloading Proprietary Software

                                                                                          Downloading Proprietary Software (without permission from the Copyright Owner) is identical to stealing physical property. Stealing physical property is morally wrong. Therefore, downloading proprietary software (without permission) is morally wrong.

                                                                                           

                                                                                          7 Step Strategy for Evaluating Arguments

                                                                                          Step 1 – Convert into Standard form

                                                                                          Premise 1 – Downloading Proprietary Software without permission is identical to stealing physical       property

                                                                                          Premise 2 – Stealing physical property is morally wrong

                                                                                          Conclusion - Downloading Proprietary Software without permission is morally wrong

                                                                                          Step 2 – Test whether argument is Valid or Invalid

                                                                                                        Argument is valid, there is no counterexample

                                                                                          Step 3 – Is the argument valid ? Yes

                                                                                          Step 4 – Is the valid argument Sound? Yes, all Premises are true in the actual world

                                                                                          Step 5 – Is the invalid argument inductive or fallacious – Not applicable

                                                                                          Step 6 – The premises are true in the actual world

                                                                                          Step 7 – Overall Assesment

                                                                                          1. Copyright is 100% automatically assumed by the Creator / Owner. Any use other works without the owners permission is morally wrong
                                                                                          2. Downloading copyrighted software is equivalent to stealing physical property. Stealing is morally wrong

                                                                                          The arguments overall strength is sound, valid and inductive with true premises.

                                                                                          Activity Two – Classify the Given Statements

                                                                                          Argument

                                                                                          Fallacy Name

                                                                                          John is a con artist. John has black hair. Therefore, all people with black hair are con artists.

                                                                                          Composition

                                                                                           

                                                                                          A politician degrading another politician during a political campaign when asked about a specific policy – “Well, I think we need to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic.”

                                                                                          Ad Hominem

                                                                                          There is a lot of commotion regarding saving the environment. We cannot make this world an Eden. What will happen if it does become Eden? Adam and Eve got bored there!

                                                                                          False Dichotomy of False Dilema

                                                                                          Child to parent: Either you buy me this new book, or you decide that reading is not important at all.

                                                                                          Appeal to Authority

                                                                                          If we allow the children to choose the movie this time, they are going to expect to be able to choose the school they go to or the doctors they visit.

                                                                                          Slippery Slope

                                                                                           

                                                                                           

                                                                                          Activity Three - Define the following terms and explain their use

                                                                                           

                                                                                          1. What is the role of the Thesis Statement in the introduction of an essay paper?

                                                                                          The Thesis Statement in an essay is about figuring out the main idea for the essay and then explaining that to the reader in the paper. It outlines what the paper is about and helps the writer focus on the subject or argument of the paper.

                                                                                          www.cws.illinois.edu/workshop/writers/tips/thesis/Links to an external site.

                                                                                          1. What is a Topic Sentence for a paragraph?

                                                                                          After the writer decides on their position in an argument, they write paragraphs to support their position and Topic Sentence is the sentence that contains the main idea that will be discussed in a paragraph.

                                                                                          https://www.matrix.edu.au/how-to-write-a-topic-sentence/Links to an external site.

                                                                                          1. What is an argument? How is it structured?

                                                                                          An argument is the main idea that is to be discussed in an essay. It is the main idea or claim that must be justified with reasons. It consists of group of statements that support each other towards the conclusion.

                                                                                          https://criticalthinkersworld.wordpress.com/the-basic-structure-of-argument/

                                                                                          1. What is an assumptions?

                                                                                          When writing an essay and defending a position, the writer makes statements without trying to prove them, the writer simply assumes that those statements are true …these are assumptions

                                                                                          https://app.shoreline.edu/doldham/101/HTML/Assumptions.htmLinks to an external site.

                                                                                           

                                                                                          5. What are the assumptions of the following arguments?

                                                                                           

                                                                                          The assumption is that the US President failed to deliver his promise of 2008 because over 12 million USA Citizens were unemployed in 2012.

                                                                                          The writer does not attempt to provide evidence to prove that 12 million citizens were unemployed.

                                                                                           

                                                                                          The assumption is that Chilean students were right to protest that Uni education should be free.

                                                                                          The writer does not prove why their action to protest was right…

                                                                                           

                                                                                           

                                                                                           

                                                                                           

                                                                                          •

Things = Jon Properties = Con artist & Black Hair My view is that there is only one thing - Jon linked to those two properties ... thats why I ruled that out   My reason for choosing Composition Whole = Jon Parts of a Whole = Jons black Hair Characteristics of the Whole = Con Artist :) ...                                                                                               • Go To Parent

                                                                                              Hi Jeannette 

                                                                                              Yeah .. just looking through your answers ... while we wait for the correct answers .. lets try dissect our answers ... 

                                                                                              Firstly Guilt by Association ... two things share some properties ...

                                                                                              Things = Jon

                                                                                              Properties = Con artist & Black Hair

                                                                                              My view is that there is only one thing - Jon linked to those two properties ... thats why I ruled that out

                                                                                               

                                                                                              My reason for choosing Composition

                                                                                              Whole = Jon

                                                                                              Parts of a Whole = Jons black Hair

                                                                                              Characteristics of the Whole = Con Artist

                                                                                            Collapse Subdiscussion Edward Davis

                                                                                            Edward Davis

                                                                                            Sep 15, 2018 Sep 15, 2018 at 9:31
                                                                                            From the second activity I found that certain fallacies can be considered sub-categories or types of other simpler fallacies.Example:A politician degrading another politician during a politicalcampaign when asked about a specific policy – “Well, I think weneed to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic.”This argument could be referred to as an Ad Hominem, as politician A directly attacks politician B with the inclusion of 'other candidate's failures'.This could also been seen as a Red Herring, as politician A attempts to move the discussion from their policies to politician B's policies.Based off this one could say that an Ad Hominem is an informal Red Herring, where participant A is advertently changing the topic discussion to participant B's attributes. Is this assumption correct or am I going too far down the rabbit hole?Cheers,Edward
                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                            • Go To Topic

                                                                                            From the second activity I found that certain fallacies can be considered sub-categories or types of other simpler fallacies.

                                                                                            Example:
                                                                                            A politician degrading another politician during a political
                                                                                            campaign when asked about a specific policy – “Well, I think we
                                                                                            need to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic.”

                                                                                            This argument could be referred to as an Ad Hominem, as politician A directly attacks politician B with the inclusion of 'other candidate's failures'.
                                                                                            This could also been seen as a Red Herring, as politician A attempts to move the discussion from their policies to politician B's policies.

                                                                                            Based off this one could say that an Ad Hominem is an informal Red Herring, where participant A is advertently changing the topic discussion to participant B's attributes. Is this assumption correct or am I going too far down the rabbit hole?

                                                                                            Cheers,

                                                                                            Edward




                                                                                            •
                                                                                              Jo Klein

                                                                                              Jo Klein

                                                                                              Sep 15, 2018 Sep 15, 2018 at 11:36
                                                                                              Hi Edward, I am not sure by what you mean sub-categories of fallacies.  Isn't 10 enough to deal with...? I know it's not always absolutely clear which Fallacy is relevant, but one is usually more applicable than the others.  I think the example: A politician degrading another politician during a political campaign when asked about a specific policy – “Well, I think we need to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic.”, is definitely Ad Hominem , because the candidate is attacking the other candidate and trying to discredit the other candidate, whereas Red Herring Fallacy  is used to change a subject and confuse an issue. Just my thoughts
                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                              • Go To Parent

                                                                                              Hi Edward,

                                                                                              I am not sure by what you mean sub-categories of fallacies.  Isn't 10 enough to deal with...?

                                                                                              I know it's not always absolutely clear which Fallacy is relevant, but one is usually more applicable than the others.  I think the example:

                                                                                              A politician degrading another politician during a political campaign when asked about a specific policy – “Well, I think we need to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic.”, is definitely Ad Hominem , because the candidate is attacking the other candidate and trying to discredit the other candidate, whereas Red Herring Fallacy  is used to change a subject and confuse an issue.

                                                                                              Just my thoughts

                                                                                              •
                                                                                                Shyam Nath

                                                                                                Shyam Nath

                                                                                                Sep 17, 2018 Sep 17, 2018 at 8:25
                                                                                                🖖 Hello Edward, and Joanne,   It cannot be ad hominem; the politician is attacking someone else, but the dispute only concerns their own policy, so the attack is off topic since the dispute does not concern the other candidates' policy ∴ I consider the politicians' syllogism a red herring.   Wikipedia has guilt by association as a type of ad hominem. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ad_hominem#Types https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_fallacy#Guilt_by_association_as_an_ad_hominem_fallacy   Wikipedia also has, "An association fallacy is an informal inductive fallacy of the hasty-generalization or red-herring type and which asserts, by irrelevant association and often by appeal to emotion, that qualities of one thing are inherently qualities of another." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_fallacy   LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,AGENT S.🕴Migrating Infestive Bugs !!
                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                • Go To Parent
                                                                                                🖖 Hello Edward, and Joanne,
                                                                                                 
                                                                                                It cannot be ad hominem; the politician is attacking someone else, but the dispute only concerns their own policy, so the attack is off topic since the dispute does not concern the other candidates' policy ∴ I consider the politicians' syllogism a red herring.
                                                                                                 
                                                                                                Wikipedia has guilt by association as a type of ad hominem.
                                                                                                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ad_hominem#Types
                                                                                                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_fallacy#Guilt_by_association_as_an_ad_hominem_fallacy
                                                                                                 
                                                                                                Wikipedia also has, "An association fallacy is an informal inductive fallacy of the hasty-generalization or red-herring type and which asserts, by irrelevant association and often by appeal to emotion, that qualities of one thing are inherently qualities of another."
                                                                                                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_fallacy

                                                                                                Collapse Subdiscussion Bernard Jacques Labigang

                                                                                                Bernard Jacques Labigang

                                                                                                Sep 15, 2018 Sep 15, 2018 at 20:49
                                                                                                Here is my view on activity 1:  Following the seven steps strategy:   Example 1 - All trees are plants. - The redwood is a tree. - Therefore, redwood is a plant.   The argument is valid Now let’s consider this: Depending of the context, a tree can be something different. What I mean is that we could assume that we are not talking of the botanical organism here. In that case, what if we consider a family tree for example. This is clearly not a plant. So, premise 1 is false. That makes the argument unsound.   Example 2 - All basketballs are round. - The Earth is round. - Therefore, the Earth is a basketball.   I can replace the earth by another round object (a bowling ball for example. A bowling ball is certainly not a basketball. The counterexample makes the argument invalid. It is very unlikely that the conclusion would be true even when the premises are assumed true. I see this as a slippery slope fallacy.   Example 3 - All GPS satellites are positioned underwater. - Everything positioned underwater becomes wet. - Therefore, GPS satellites are wet. The argument is valid based on: Every A is a B, C is an A, therefore C is a B However, the argument is not sound as satellites are not positioned under water.   Example 4 - Beckham is famous. - Beckham is a football player. - Therefore, Beckham is a famous football player. This is invalid because a counterexample exists.  If I replace Beckham by Usain Bolt,             Usain Bolt is famous.             Usain Bolt is a football player.             Therefore, Usain Bolt is a famous football player. Usain Bolt is famous, yes, but for his career in athletics, not in football (soccer).  He just started his new career in football, playing for an Australian club. That doesn’t qualify him as a famous football player. This an inductive argument. Beckham is definitely a famous football player.             Example 5 - Some of the computer programmers play piano. - No one who plays piano watches footy matches. - Some computer programmers watch footy matches. Invalid argument if assumed both premises are true, as some of those computer programmers who don’t play piano could possibly watch footy matches but no guarantee of that. I would put this argument as inductive.   Cheers Bernard
                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                • Go To Topic

                                                                                                Here is my view on activity 1:

                                                                                                 Following the seven steps strategy:

                                                                                                 

                                                                                                Example 1 - All trees are plants.

                                                                                                - The redwood is a tree.

                                                                                                - Therefore, redwood is a plant.

                                                                                                 

                                                                                                The argument is valid

                                                                                                Now let’s consider this:

                                                                                                Depending of the context, a tree can be something different. What I mean is that we could assume that we are not talking of the botanical organism here. In that case, what if we consider a family tree for example. This is clearly not a plant. So, premise 1 is false.

                                                                                                That makes the argument unsound.

                                                                                                 

                                                                                                Example 2 - All basketballs are round.

                                                                                                - The Earth is round.

                                                                                                - Therefore, the Earth is a basketball.

                                                                                                 

                                                                                                I can replace the earth by another round object (a bowling ball for example. A bowling ball is certainly not a basketball. The counterexample makes the argument invalid.

                                                                                                It is very unlikely that the conclusion would be true even when the premises are assumed true. I see this as a slippery slope fallacy.

                                                                                                 

                                                                                                Example 3 - All GPS satellites are positioned underwater.

                                                                                                - Everything positioned underwater becomes wet.

                                                                                                - Therefore, GPS satellites are wet.

                                                                                                The argument is valid based on: Every A is a B, C is an A, therefore C is a B

                                                                                                However, the argument is not sound as satellites are not positioned under water.

                                                                                                 

                                                                                                Example 4 - Beckham is famous.

                                                                                                - Beckham is a football player.

                                                                                                - Therefore, Beckham is a famous football player.

                                                                                                This is invalid because a counterexample exists.

                                                                                                 If I replace Beckham by Usain Bolt,

                                                                                                            Usain Bolt is famous.

                                                                                                            Usain Bolt is a football player.

                                                                                                            Therefore, Usain Bolt is a famous football player.

                                                                                                Usain Bolt is famous, yes, but for his career in athletics, not in football (soccer).

                                                                                                 He just started his new career in football, playing for an Australian club.

                                                                                                That doesn’t qualify him as a famous football player.

                                                                                                This an inductive argument. Beckham is definitely a famous football player.

                                                                                                           

                                                                                                Example 5 - Some of the computer programmers play piano.

                                                                                                - No one who plays piano watches footy matches.

                                                                                                - Some computer programmers watch footy matches.

                                                                                                Invalid argument if assumed both premises are true, as some of those computer programmers who don’t play piano could possibly watch footy matches but no guarantee of that.

                                                                                                I would put this argument as inductive.

                                                                                                 

                                                                                                Cheers

                                                                                                Bernard

                                                                                                    Shyam Nath

                                                                                                    Shyam Nath

                                                                                                    Sep 16, 2018 Sep 16, 2018 at 14:41
                                                                                                    🖖 Hello World,   Activity 1 1) P(2): Stealing physical property is morally wrong. P(1): Downloading proprietary software (without permission) is identical to stealing physical property. C(0)∴ Downloading proprietary software (without permission) is morally wrong. 2) The argument is valid ∵ I've no counterexample, and the colour-coding shows how the conclusion follows from the premises; "stealing physical property" is the middle term. 3) Yes, the argument is valid. 4) The argument is unsound ∵ in the actual world, downloading proprietary software (without permission) is not identical to stealing physical property; downloading software does not remove possession of the software from any of the owners. 6) No, at least one of the premises is false in the actual world. 7) The argument is weak ∵ it is valid, but unsound (#2).   Example 1 1) P(2): The redwood is a tree. P(1): All trees are plants. C(0)∴ Redwood is a plant. 2) The argument is valid ∵ I've no counterexample, and the colour-coding shows how the conclusion follows from the premises; "tree" is the middle term. 3) Yes, the argument is valid. 4) The argument is sound ∵ all of the premises are true in the actual world. 6) Yes, all of the premises are true in the actual world. 7) The argument is strong ∵ it is sound (#1).   Example 2 1) P(2): The Earth is round. P(1): All basketballs are round. C(0)∴ The Earth is a basketball. 2) The argument is invalid ∵ the conclusion doesn't follow from the premises; two "-thing"s being round, does not mean they are the same "-thing". 3) No, the argument is invalid. 5) The argument is fallacious ∵ the Earth is a beachball, which is very different from a basketball. 6) Yes, all of the premises are true in the actual world. 7) The argument is weak ∵ it is fallacious with some mixture of true and false premises (#5).   Example 3 1) P(2): Everything positioned underwater becomes wet. P(1): All GPS satellites are positioned underwater. C(0)∴ GPS satellites are wet. 2) The argument is valid ∵ I've no counterexample, and the colour-coding shows how the conclusion follows from the premises; "positioned underwater" is the middle term. 3) Yes, the argument is valid. 4) The argument is unsound ∵ in the actual world, all GPS satellites are not positioned underwater. 6) No, at least one of the premises is false in the actual world. 7) The argument is weak ∵ it is valid, but unsound (#2).   Example 4 1) P(2): Beckham is a football player. P(1): Beckham is famous. C(0)∴ Beckham is a famous football player. 2) The argument is valid ∵ I've no counterexample, and the colour-coding shows how the conclusion follows from the premises; "famous" is an adjective, and "football player" is a noun. 3) Yes, the argument is valid. 4) The argument is unsound ∵ Beckham is a retired football player in the actual world ∴ to correct P(2); Beckham was a football player. 6) No, at least one of the premises is false in the actual world. 7) The argument is weak ∵ it is valid, but unsound (#2).   Example 5 1) P(2): No one who plays piano watches footy matches. P(1): Some of the computer programmers play piano. C(0)∴ Some computer programmers watch footy matches. 2) The argument is invalid ∵ it is unsupported by the premises; that any of the computer programmers, who do not play the piano, watch footy matches. 3) No, the argument is invalid. 5) The argument is fallacious ∵ there may be pianists who watch footy matches. 6) No, at least one of the premises is false in the actual world. 7) The argument is weak ∵ it is fallacious with some mixture of true and false premises (#5).   Activity 2 1) Guilt by Association. John is a con artist. John has black hair. Therefore, all people with black hair are con artists. 2) Red Herring. A politician degrading another politician during a political campaign when asked about a specific policy – "Well, I think we need to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic." 3) Straw Man. There is a lot of commotion regarding saving the environment. We cannot make this world an Eden. What will happen if it does become Eden? Adam and Eve got bored there! 4) False Dichotomy, or False Dilemma. Child to parent: Either you buy me this new book, or you decide that reading is not important at all. 5) Slippery Slope. If we allow the children to choose the movie this time, they are going to expect to be able to choose the school they go to or the doctors they visit.   Activity 3 1) The thesis statement is a lapidary recapitulation of the salient asseverations established by the essay/paper. 2) The topic sentence is a lapidary recapitulation of the salient asseverations established by the paragraph. 3) An argument is a collection of claims; structured in the form of a list of premises, followed by a conclusion. 4) An assumption is the acceptance of unproven veracity. 5a) The assumption is that 12 million unemployed citizens means the country'd entered into economic depression. 5b) The assumption is that the Chilean students were right.   LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,AGENT S.🕴Migrating Infestive Bugs !!
                                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                    • Go To Topic
                                                                                                    🖖 Hello World,
                                                                                                     
                                                                                                    Activity 1
                                                                                                    1)
                                                                                                    P(2): Stealing physical property is morally wrong.
                                                                                                    P(1): Downloading proprietary software (without permission) is identical to stealing physical property.
                                                                                                    C(0)∴ Downloading proprietary software (without permission) is morally wrong.
                                                                                                    2) The argument is valid ∵ I've no counterexample, and the colour-coding shows how the conclusion follows from the premises; "stealing physical property" is the middle term.
                                                                                                    3) Yes, the argument is valid.
                                                                                                    4) The argument is unsound ∵ in the actual world, downloading proprietary software (without permission) is not identical to stealing physical property; downloading software does not remove possession of the software from any of the owners.
                                                                                                    6) No, at least one of the premises is false in the actual world.
                                                                                                    7) The argument is weak ∵ it is valid, but unsound (#2).
                                                                                                     
                                                                                                    Example 1
                                                                                                    1)
                                                                                                    P(2): The redwood is a tree.
                                                                                                    P(1): All trees are plants.
                                                                                                    C(0)∴ Redwood is a plant.
                                                                                                    2) The argument is valid ∵ I've no counterexample, and the colour-coding shows how the conclusion follows from the premises; "tree" is the middle term.
                                                                                                    3) Yes, the argument is valid.
                                                                                                    4) The argument is sound ∵ all of the premises are true in the actual world.

                                                                                                    6) Yes, all of the premises are true in the actual world.

                                                                                                    7) The argument is strong ∵ it is sound (#1).
                                                                                                     
                                                                                                    Example 2
                                                                                                    1)
                                                                                                    P(2): The Earth is round.
                                                                                                    P(1): All basketballs are round.
                                                                                                    C(0)∴ The Earth is a basketball.
                                                                                                    2) The argument is invalid ∵ the conclusion doesn't follow from the premises; two "-thing"s being round, does not mean they are the same "-thing".
                                                                                                    3) No, the argument is invalid.
                                                                                                    5) The argument is fallacious ∵ the Earth is a beachball, which is very different from a basketball.
                                                                                                    6) Yes, all of the premises are true in the actual world.
                                                                                                    7) The argument is weak ∵ it is fallacious with some mixture of true and false premises (#5).
                                                                                                     
                                                                                                    Example 3
                                                                                                    1)
                                                                                                    P(2): Everything positioned underwater becomes wet.
                                                                                                    P(1): All GPS satellites are positioned underwater.
                                                                                                    C(0)∴ GPS satellites are wet.
                                                                                                    2) The argument is valid ∵ I've no counterexample, and the colour-coding shows how the conclusion follows from the premises; "positioned underwater" is the middle term.
                                                                                                    3) Yes, the argument is valid.
                                                                                                    4) The argument is unsound ∵ in the actual world, all GPS satellites are not positioned underwater.

                                                                                                    6) No, at least one of the premises is false in the actual world.

                                                                                                    7) The argument is weak ∵ it is valid, but unsound (#2).
                                                                                                     
                                                                                                    Example 4
                                                                                                    1)
                                                                                                    P(2): Beckham is a football player.
                                                                                                    P(1): Beckham is famous.
                                                                                                    C(0)∴ Beckham is a famous football player.
                                                                                                    2) The argument is valid ∵ I've no counterexample, and the colour-coding shows how the conclusion follows from the premises; "famous" is an adjective, and "football player" is a noun.
                                                                                                    3) Yes, the argument is valid.

                                                                                                    4) The argument is unsound ∵ Beckham is a retired football player in the actual world ∴ to correct P(2); Beckham was a football player.

                                                                                                    6) No, at least one of the premises is false in the actual world.
                                                                                                    7) The argument is weak ∵ it is valid, but unsound (#2).

                                                                                                     

                                                                                                    Example 5
                                                                                                    1)
                                                                                                    P(2): No one who plays piano watches footy matches.
                                                                                                    P(1): Some of the computer programmers play piano.
                                                                                                    C(0)∴ Some computer programmers watch footy matches.
                                                                                                    2) The argument is invalid ∵ it is unsupported by the premises; that any of the computer programmers, who do not play the piano, watch footy matches.
                                                                                                    3) No, the argument is invalid.

                                                                                                    5) The argument is fallacious ∵ there may be pianists who watch footy matches.

                                                                                                    6) No, at least one of the premises is false in the actual world.
                                                                                                    7) The argument is weak ∵ it is fallacious with some mixture of true and false premises (#5).
                                                                                                     
                                                                                                    Activity 2
                                                                                                    1) Guilt by Association.
                                                                                                    John is a con artist. John has black hair. Therefore, all people with black hair are con artists.
                                                                                                    2) Red Herring.
                                                                                                    A politician degrading another politician during a political campaign when asked about a specific policy – "Well, I think we need to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic."
                                                                                                    3) Straw Man.
                                                                                                    There is a lot of commotion regarding saving the environment. We cannot make this world an Eden. What will happen if it does become Eden? Adam and Eve got bored there!
                                                                                                    4) False Dichotomy, or False Dilemma.

                                                                                                    Child to parent: Either you buy me this new book, or you decide that reading is not important at all.

                                                                                                    5) Slippery Slope.

                                                                                                    If we allow the children to choose the movie this time, they are going to expect to be able to choose the school they go to or the doctors they visit.

                                                                                                     
                                                                                                    Activity 3
                                                                                                    1) The thesis statement is a lapidary recapitulation of the salient asseverations established by the essay/paper.
                                                                                                    2) The topic sentence is a lapidary recapitulation of the salient asseverations established by the paragraph.
                                                                                                    3) An argument is a collection of claims; structured in the form of a list of premises, followed by a conclusion.
                                                                                                    4) An assumption is the acceptance of unproven veracity.
                                                                                                    5a) The assumption is that 12 million unemployed citizens means the country'd entered into economic depression.
                                                                                                    5b) The assumption is that the Chilean students were right.
                                                                                                     

                                                                                                    LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
                                                                                                    AGENT S.
                                                                                                    🕴
                                                                                                    Migrating Infestive Bugs !!

                                                                                                    Edited by Shyam Nath on Sep 16, 2018 at 14:43
