                                                                                                      Collapse Subdiscussion Shyam Nath

                                                                                                      Shyam Nath

                                                                                                      Sep 16, 2018 Sep 16, 2018 at 16:00
                                                                                                      🖖 Hello World,   In discrete mathematics, we're also studying arguments.   Arguments are always valid if the premises are assumed true, and the conclusion is a conjunction, inclusive/exclusive disjunction, implication, or equivalence; these may be "unsound" arguments, but the conclusion can still be provably true regardless, so IDK…I guess arguments can be valid + unsound + strong ∵ the truth of the conclusion is guaranteed by use of pure mathematical logic, and not due to fawlty reasoning.   P(2): True P(1): False C(0)∴ P(1) ∨ P(2)   P(2): FalseP(1): TrueC(0)∴ P(1) ∨ P(2)   P(2): TrueP(1): FalseC(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)P(2): FalseP(1): TrueC(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)   P(2): TrueP(1): FalseC(0)∴ P(1) → P(2)   P(2): FalseP(1): FalseC(0)∴ P(1) → P(2)   P(2): FalseP(1): FalseC(0)∴ P(1) ↔ P(2)   Those conclusions are all true ∴ the arguments are strong, regardless of audibility.   LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,AGENT S.🕴Migrating Infestive Bugs !!
                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                      • Go To Topic
                                                                                                      🖖 Hello World,
                                                                                                       
                                                                                                      In discrete mathematicsLinks to an external site., we're also studying arguments.
                                                                                                       
                                                                                                      Arguments are always valid if the premises are assumed true, and the conclusion is a conjunction, inclusive/exclusive disjunction, implication, or equivalence; these may be "unsound" arguments, but the conclusion can still be provably true regardless, so IDK…I guess arguments can be valid + unsound + strong ∵ the truth of the conclusion is guaranteed by use of pure mathematical logic, and not due to fawlty reasoning.
                                                                                                       
                                                                                                      P(2): True
                                                                                                      P(1): False
                                                                                                      C(0)∴ P(1) ∨ P(2)
                                                                                                       
                                                                                                      P(2): False
                                                                                                      P(1): True
                                                                                                      C(0)∴ P(1) ∨ P(2)
                                                                                                       
                                                                                                      P(2): True
                                                                                                      P(1): False
                                                                                                      C(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)

                                                                                                      P(2): False
                                                                                                      P(1): True
                                                                                                      C(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)
                                                                                                       
                                                                                                      P(2): True
                                                                                                      P(1): False
                                                                                                      C(0)∴ P(1) → P(2)
                                                                                                       
                                                                                                      P(2): False
                                                                                                      P(1): False
                                                                                                      C(0)∴ P(1) → P(2)
                                                                                                       
                                                                                                      P(2): False
                                                                                                      P(1): False
                                                                                                      C(0)∴ P(1) ↔ P(2)
                                                                                                       
                                                                                                      Those conclusions are all true ∴ the arguments are strong, regardless of audibility.
                                                                                                       

                                                                                                      LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
                                                                                                      AGENT S.
                                                                                                      🕴
                                                                                                      Migrating Infestive Bugs !!

                                                                                                      •
                                                                                                        Collapse Subdiscussion Shyam Nath

                                                                                                        Shyam Nath

                                                                                                        Sep 16, 2018 Sep 16, 2018 at 16:05
                                                                                                        PS: In fact, exclusive disjunction allows for arguments that are invalid + inductive + weak.   P(2): TrueP(1): TrueC(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)   This conclusion is false.
                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                        • Go To Parent
                                                                                                        PS: In fact, exclusive disjunction allows for arguments that are invalid + inductive + weak.
                                                                                                         
                                                                                                        P(2): True
                                                                                                        P(1): True
                                                                                                        C(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)
                                                                                                         
                                                                                                        This conclusion is false.
                                                                                                        Edited by Shyam Nath on Sep 16, 2018 at 16:49
                                                                                                        •
                                                                                                          Collapse Subdiscussion Shyam Nath

                                                                                                          Shyam Nath

                                                                                                          Sep 16, 2018 Sep 16, 2018 at 16:55
                                                                                                          PSS: These arguments are actually invalid + fallacious + strong.   P(2): TrueP(1): FalseC(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)P(2): FalseP(1): True C(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)   These conclusions are true.
                                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                          • Go To Parent
                                                                                                          PSS: These arguments are actually invalid + fallacious + strong.
                                                                                                           

                                                                                                          P(2): True
                                                                                                          P(1): False
                                                                                                          C(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)

                                                                                                          P(2): False
                                                                                                          P(1): True

                                                                                                          C(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)
                                                                                                           
                                                                                                          These conclusions are true.
                                                                                                          •
                                                                                                            Collapse Subdiscussion Shyam Nath

                                                                                                            Shyam Nath

                                                                                                            Sep 18, 2018 Sep 18, 2018 at 0:19
                                                                                                            PSSS: Tautological implication means all the premises can be contradictory, and the argument is strong; it involves premisory conjunction implicating the conclusion, which can be false & strong at the same time. If all the premises are false; the argument is strong, regardless of the conclusion, due to the tautological implication.   P(1): 1 + 1 = ⊞ C(0)∴ No one is more intelligent than me!!! :D
                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                            • Go To Parent
                                                                                                            PSSS: Tautological implication means all the premises can be contradictory, and the argument is strong; it involves premisory conjunction implicating the conclusion, which can be false & strong at the same time. If all the premises are false; the argument is strong, regardless of the conclusion, due to the tautological implication.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            P(1): 1 + 1 = ⊞

                                                                                                            C(0)∴ No one is more intelligent than me!!! :D

                                                                                                            •
                                                                                                              Collapse Subdiscussion Shyam Nath

                                                                                                              Shyam Nath

                                                                                                              Sep 18, 2018 Sep 18, 2018 at 11:23
                                                                                                              PSSSS: There're other techniques for (dis)proving arguments.   Argument Structure P = P(1) ∧ P(2) ∧ P(3) ∧ … Q = C(0) P → Q   Direct Proofs Assume P is true Deduce Q is true ∵ P → Q   Contrapositive Proofs Assume Q is false Deduce P is false ∵ (P → Q) = (¬Q → ¬P)   Contradictory Proofs Assume P is true Assume Q is false Disprove P ∧ Q ∵ (P → Q) = ¬(P ∧ ¬Q)   Trivial Proofs Trivially true when ⊨Q(x) ∵ ∀x: P(x) → Q(x)   Vacuous Proofs Vacuously true when ⊭P(x) ∵ ∀x: P(x) → Q(x)   Counterexample Disproofs Prove ¬P ∵ ¬P → P :  T → F = F   Inductive Proofs (P(1) ∧ (∀k: P(k) → P(k + 1))) → (∀n: P(n)), where k ≥ 1 ≤ n (This is W4 stuff; I haven't started yet, so it's above my adroitness…)   Food For Thought I've noted, out of pure interest/ambition/ETC:  ‣ Predicate Calculus uses: (Automated) Theorem Proving software, and inference engine design for knowledge-based (expert) systems.  ‣ Proof By Induction uses: Some theorems concerning properties of integers, and with applications to algorithm analysis.   IDK what it all means, but I'm excited nonetheless!!! :D
                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                              • Go To Parent
                                                                                                              PSSSS: There're other techniques for (dis)proving arguments.
                                                                                                               
                                                                                                              Argument Structure

                                                                                                              P = P(1) ∧ P(2) ∧ P(3) ∧ …

                                                                                                              Q = C(0)
                                                                                                              P → Q
                                                                                                               
                                                                                                              Direct Proofs
                                                                                                              Assume P is true
                                                                                                              Deduce Q is true
                                                                                                              ∵ P → Q
                                                                                                               
                                                                                                              Contrapositive Proofs
                                                                                                              Assume Q is false
                                                                                                              Deduce P is false
                                                                                                              ∵ (P → Q) = (¬Q → ¬P)
                                                                                                               
                                                                                                              Contradictory Proofs
                                                                                                              Assume P is true
                                                                                                              Assume Q is false
                                                                                                              Disprove P ∧ Q
                                                                                                              ∵ (P → Q) = ¬(P ∧ ¬Q)
                                                                                                               
                                                                                                              Trivial Proofs
                                                                                                              Trivially true when ⊨Q(x)
                                                                                                              ∵ ∀x: P(x) → Q(x)
                                                                                                               
                                                                                                              Vacuous Proofs
                                                                                                              Vacuously true when ⊭P(x)
                                                                                                              ∵ ∀x: P(x) → Q(x)
                                                                                                               
                                                                                                              Counterexample Disproofs
                                                                                                              Prove ¬P
                                                                                                              ∵ ¬P → P
                                                                                                              :  T → F = F
                                                                                                               
                                                                                                              Inductive Proofs
                                                                                                              (P(1) ∧ (∀k: P(k) → P(k + 1))) → (∀n: P(n)), where k ≥ 1 ≤ n
                                                                                                              (This is W4 stuff; I haven't started yet, so it's above my adroitness…)
                                                                                                               
                                                                                                              Food For Thought
                                                                                                              I've noted, out of pure interest/ambition/ETC:
                                                                                                               ‣ Predicate Calculus uses: (Automated) Theorem Proving software, and inference engine design for knowledge-based (expert) systems.
                                                                                                               ‣ Proof By Induction uses: Some theorems concerning properties of integers, and with applications to algorithm analysis.
                                                                                                               
                                                                                                              IDK what it all means, but I'm excited nonetheless!!! :D
                                                                                                              Edited by Shyam Nath on Sep 18, 2018 at 11:57
                                                                                                              •
                                                                                                                Collapse Subdiscussion Shyam Nath

                                                                                                                Shyam Nath

                                                                                                      Samuel Prentice

                                                                                                      Sep 17, 2018 Sep 17, 2018 at 13:04
                                                                                                      Hi All, I guess I missed this one but here's one from the weekend. The Facts. our Esky is broken, our family enjoys camping Alot.  Ice boxes are better at keeping ice from melting. Esky's are cheaper I'm married. My argument is pro icebox upgrade, sure it costs a little more but it'll last longer and keep the ice colder, my wife opposes this argument & wants to just buy another esky. Like i said, I'm married therefore My argument is invalid & fallacious. Esky wins. Not really, the wife also wants an icebox but I hope you had a lol :) catch you next time. Sam.
                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                      • Go To Topic

                                                                                                      Hi All,

                                                                                                      I guess I missed this one but here's one from the weekend.

                                                                                                      The Facts.

                                                                                                      • our Esky is broken,
                                                                                                      • our family enjoys camping Alot. 
                                                                                                      • Ice boxes are better at keeping ice from melting.
                                                                                                      • Esky's are cheaper
                                                                                                      • I'm married.

                                                                                                      My argument is pro icebox upgrade, sure it costs a little more but it'll last longer and keep the ice colder, my wife opposes this argument & wants to just buy another esky.

                                                                                                      Like i said, I'm married therefore My argument is invalid & fallacious. Esky wins.

                                                                                                      Not really, the wife also wants an icebox but I hope you had a lol :) catch you next time.

                                                                                                      Sam.

                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                        • Go To Topic
                                                                                                        🖖 Hello World,
                                                                                                         
                                                                                                         
                                                                                                        Vsauce2 has a Logic and ReasoningLinks to an external site. playlist; it's new, and there's a good chance more videos will be added as time continues.

                                                                                                        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
                                                                                                        AGENT S.
                                                                                                        🕴
                                                                                                        Migrating Infestive Bugs !!

                                                                                                          •
                                                                                                            Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Sep 16, 2018 Sep 16, 2018 at 14:41
                                                                                                            🖖 Hello World,
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Activity 1
                                                                                                            1)
                                                                                                            P(2): Stealing physical property is morally wrong.
                                                                                                            P(1): Downloading proprietary software (without permission) is identical to stealing physical property.
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ Downloading proprietary software (without permission) is morally wrong.
                                                                                                            2) The argument is valid ∵ I've no counterexample, and the colour-coding shows how the conclusion follows from the premises; "stealing physical property" is the middle term.
                                                                                                            3) Yes, the argument is valid.
                                                                                                            4) The argument is unsound ∵ in the actual world, downloading proprietary software (without permission) is not identical to stealing physical property; downloading software does not remove possession of the software from any of the owners.
                                                                                                            6) No, at least one of the premises is false in the actual world.
                                                                                                            7) The argument is weak ∵ it is valid, but unsound (#2).
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Example 1
                                                                                                            1)
                                                                                                            P(2): The redwood is a tree.
                                                                                                            P(1): All trees are plants.
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ Redwood is a plant.
                                                                                                            2) The argument is valid ∵ I've no counterexample, and the colour-coding shows how the conclusion follows from the premises; "tree" is the middle term.
                                                                                                            3) Yes, the argument is valid.
                                                                                                            4) The argument is sound ∵ all of the premises are true in the actual world.

                                                                                                            6) Yes, all of the premises are true in the actual world.

                                                                                                            7) The argument is strong ∵ it is sound (#1).
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Example 2
                                                                                                            1)
                                                                                                            P(2): The Earth is round.
                                                                                                            P(1): All basketballs are round.
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ The Earth is a basketball.
                                                                                                            2) The argument is invalid ∵ the conclusion doesn't follow from the premises; two "-thing"s being round, does not mean they are the same "-thing".
                                                                                                            3) No, the argument is invalid.
                                                                                                            5) The argument is fallacious ∵ the Earth is a beachball, which is very different from a basketball.
                                                                                                            6) Yes, all of the premises are true in the actual world.
                                                                                                            7) The argument is weak ∵ it is fallacious with some mixture of true and false premises (#5).
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Example 3
                                                                                                            1)
                                                                                                            P(2): Everything positioned underwater becomes wet.
                                                                                                            P(1): All GPS satellites are positioned underwater.
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ GPS satellites are wet.
                                                                                                            2) The argument is valid ∵ I've no counterexample, and the colour-coding shows how the conclusion follows from the premises; "positioned underwater" is the middle term.
                                                                                                            3) Yes, the argument is valid.
                                                                                                            4) The argument is unsound ∵ in the actual world, all GPS satellites are not positioned underwater.

                                                                                                            6) No, at least one of the premises is false in the actual world.

                                                                                                            7) The argument is weak ∵ it is valid, but unsound (#2).
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Example 4
                                                                                                            1)
                                                                                                            P(2): Beckham is a football player.
                                                                                                            P(1): Beckham is famous.
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ Beckham is a famous football player.
                                                                                                            2) The argument is valid ∵ I've no counterexample, and the colour-coding shows how the conclusion follows from the premises; "famous" is an adjective, and "football player" is a noun.
                                                                                                            3) Yes, the argument is valid.

                                                                                                            4) The argument is unsound ∵ Beckham is a retired football player in the actual world ∴ to correct P(2); Beckham was a football player.

                                                                                                            6) No, at least one of the premises is false in the actual world.
                                                                                                            7) The argument is weak ∵ it is valid, but unsound (#2).

                                                                                                             

                                                                                                            Example 5
                                                                                                            1)
                                                                                                            P(2): No one who plays piano watches footy matches.
                                                                                                            P(1): Some of the computer programmers play piano.
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ Some computer programmers watch footy matches.
                                                                                                            2) The argument is invalid ∵ it is unsupported by the premises; that any of the computer programmers, who do not play the piano, watch footy matches.
                                                                                                            3) No, the argument is invalid.

                                                                                                            5) The argument is fallacious ∵ there may be pianists who watch footy matches.

                                                                                                            6) No, at least one of the premises is false in the actual world.
                                                                                                            7) The argument is weak ∵ it is fallacious with some mixture of true and false premises (#5).
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Activity 2
                                                                                                            1) Guilt by Association.
                                                                                                            John is a con artist. John has black hair. Therefore, all people with black hair are con artists.
                                                                                                            2) Red Herring.
                                                                                                            A politician degrading another politician during a political campaign when asked about a specific policy – "Well, I think we need to look at the other candidate’s failures regarding this topic."
                                                                                                            3) Straw Man.
                                                                                                            There is a lot of commotion regarding saving the environment. We cannot make this world an Eden. What will happen if it does become Eden? Adam and Eve got bored there!
                                                                                                            4) False Dichotomy, or False Dilemma.

                                                                                                            Child to parent: Either you buy me this new book, or you decide that reading is not important at all.

                                                                                                            5) Slippery Slope.

                                                                                                            If we allow the children to choose the movie this time, they are going to expect to be able to choose the school they go to or the doctors they visit.

                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Activity 3
                                                                                                            1) The thesis statement is a lapidary recapitulation of the salient asseverations established by the essay/paper.
                                                                                                            2) The topic sentence is a lapidary recapitulation of the salient asseverations established by the paragraph.
                                                                                                            3) An argument is a collection of claims; structured in the form of a list of premises, followed by a conclusion.
                                                                                                            4) An assumption is the acceptance of unproven veracity.
                                                                                                            5a) The assumption is that 12 million unemployed citizens means the country'd entered into economic depression.
                                                                                                            5b) The assumption is that the Chilean students were right.
                                                                                                             

                                                                                                            LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
                                                                                                            AGENT S.
                                                                                                            🕴
                                                                                                            Migrating Infestive Bugs !!

                                                                                                            Sep 16, 2018 Sep 16, 2018 at 15:10
                                                                                                            🖖 Hello Maxwell,
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Activity 1.4
                                                                                                            The argument only involves morality; your comments about legality are immaterial; law ≠ ethics.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Example 2
                                                                                                            I wouldn't question the definition of round (Links to an external site.), and circularity is a two-dimensional concept.
                                                                                                            Deflated basketballs are a topic (Links to an external site.) for topology (Links to an external site.); deflated basketballs are homeomorphically (Links to an external site.) round.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Example 3
                                                                                                            Before, and during, launch; GPS satellites are exposed to atmospheric humidity.
                                                                                                            Postlaunch; their orbit can decay until they land in water, and sink underwater.

                                                                                                            Sep 16, 2018 Sep 16, 2018 at 15:22
                                                                                                            🖖 Hello Darren,
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Ethics is mathematical.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Positive + Positive = Positive
                                                                                                            Positive + Negative = Depends
                                                                                                            Negative + Negative = Negative
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Stealing = Negative
                                                                                                            Philanthropy = Positive
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Stealing from Philanthropists, versus, Investing for Philanthropy? You need money to make money.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Begging is the Ethical Alternative to Stealing.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Two wrongs don't make it right.

                                                                                                          • Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Sep 16, 2018 Sep 16, 2018 at 16:00
                                                                                                            🖖 Hello World,
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            In discrete mathematics (Links to an external site.), we're also studying arguments.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Arguments are always valid if the premises are assumed true, and the conclusion is a conjunction, inclusive/exclusive disjunction, implication, or equivalence; these may be "unsound" arguments, but the conclusion can still be provably true regardless, so IDK…I guess arguments can be valid + unsound + strong ∵ the truth of the conclusion is guaranteed by use of pure mathematical logic, and not due to fawlty reasoning.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            P(2): True
                                                                                                            P(1): False
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ P(1) ∨ P(2)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            P(2): False
                                                                                                            P(1): True
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ P(1) ∨ P(2)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            P(2): True
                                                                                                            P(1): False
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)

                                                                                                            P(2): False
                                                                                                            P(1): True
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            P(2): True
                                                                                                            P(1): False
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ P(1) → P(2)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            P(2): False
                                                                                                            P(1): False
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ P(1) → P(2)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            P(2): False
                                                                                                            P(1): False
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ P(1) ↔ P(2)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Those conclusions are all true ∴ the arguments are strong, regardless of audibility.
                                                                                                             

                                                                                                            LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
                                                                                                            AGENT S.
                                                                                                            🕴
                                                                                                            Migrating Infestive Bugs !!

                                                                                                          • Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Sep 16, 2018 Sep 16, 2018 at 16:05
                                                                                                            PS: In fact, exclusive disjunction allows for arguments that are invalid + inductive + weak.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            P(2): True
                                                                                                            P(1): True
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            This conclusion is false.
                                                                                                            Edited by Shyam Nath on Sep 16, 2018 at 16:49

                                                                                                          • Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Sep 16, 2018 Sep 16, 2018 at 16:55
                                                                                                            PSS: These arguments are actually invalid + fallacious + strong.
                                                                                                             

                                                                                                            P(2): True
                                                                                                            P(1): False
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)

                                                                                                            P(2): False
                                                                                                            P(1): True

                                                                                                            C(0)∴ P(1) ⊻ P(2)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            These conclusions are true.

                                                                                                            🖖 Hello Maxwell,
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Some people make "-thing"s for themselves, and decide to sell later; in this context, there is no loss.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Some people invest resources to make "-thing"s for profit; in this context, there is a loss.

                                                                                                            🖖 Hello Jalal,
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Unfortunately, although the answer was indeed clear, simple, and straightforward, there is some difficulty in justifiably assigning to it the fourth of the epithets you applied to the statement, inasmuch as the precise correlation between the information you communicated and the facts, insofar as they can be determined and demonstrated, is such as to cause epistemological problems, of sufficient magnitude as to lay upon the logical and semantic resources of the English language a heavier burden than they can reasonably be expected to bear.

                                                                                                            🖖 Hello Sonny,
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            John can't be the only black haired con artist; there's not enough different possible hair colours for con artists to have. Also; surnames're historically occupational ∴ Johns' parents/children are most likely to be black haired con artists too.

                                                                                                            View in discussion
                                                                                                          • Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Sep 17, 2018 Sep 17, 2018 at 6:26
                                                                                                            🖖 Hello Jalal,
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Fame is normative, being known/celebrated/ETC by X people is descriptive, and…
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            P(6): In basketball, the players strategically use their feet to interact c̄ the ball.
                                                                                                            P(5): In basketball, the players use their hands to interact c̄ the ball.
                                                                                                            P(4): In handball, some rules allow the players to use their feet to interact c̄ the ball.
                                                                                                            P(3): In handball, the players use their hands to interact c̄ the ball.
                                                                                                            P(2): In "football" games, other than soccer, the players predominantly use their hands to interact c̄ the ball.
                                                                                                            P(1): In soccer, the players use their feet to interact c̄ the ball.
                                                                                                            C(0)∴ (Football = Soccer) ∧ (¬ Soccer "Football" = Basketball)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            The conclusive conjunction makes this a valid argument (assuming the verity of the premises), and the veridical premises makes this a sound argument.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            References
                                                                                                            P(4): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handball_(school)
                                                                                                            P(4): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handball#Goalkeeper
                                                                                                            P(4): https://xkcd.com/285/
                                                                                                            P(4): https://xkcd.com/978/
                                                                                                            P(6): https://woman.thenest.com/allowed-touch-basketball-legs-20572.html
                                                                                                             

                                                                                                            LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
                                                                                                            AGENT S.
                                                                                                            🕴
                                                                                                            Migrating Infestive Bugs !!

                                                                                                            Edited by Shyam Nath on Sep 17, 2018 at 6:27
                                                                                                            View in discussion
                                                                                                          • Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Sep 17, 2018 Sep 17, 2018 at 8:25
                                                                                                            🖖 Hello Edward, and Joanne,
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            It cannot be ad hominem; the politician is attacking someone else, but the dispute only concerns their own policy, so the attack is off topic since the dispute does not concern the other candidates' policy ∴ I consider the politicians' syllogism a red herring.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Wikipedia has guilt by association as a type of ad hominem.
                                                                                                            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ad_hominem#Types
                                                                                                            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_fallacy#Guilt_by_association_as_an_ad_hominem_fallacy
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Wikipedia also has, "An association fallacy is an informal inductive fallacy of the hasty-generalization or red-herring type and which asserts, by irrelevant association and often by appeal to emotion, that qualities of one thing are inherently qualities of another."
                                                                                                            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_fallacy
                                                                                                             

                                                                                                            LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,

                                                                                                          • Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Sep 17, 2018 Sep 17, 2018 at 9:15
                                                                                                            🖖 Hello Benjamin, and Scott,
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            It could also be interpreted as; they were "right in 2012" to stage the protests.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            But it's more normative to interpret it as; they were right, as in it was a good decision; as opposed to, they were in the right, or had right of way.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            It could either be; being right about staging protests to make demands, being right that university education should be free, or both.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            We cannot assume they are right about protesting, since lobbying is the right alternative.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Since free education is paid for by the tax payers; whether, or not, they are right to protest for it is an assumption.

                                                                                                            🖖 Hello Simon,
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Example 2
                                                                                                            Earth is round ∵ if you zoom in on a curve, it becomes a straight/flat ∴ a curve is either curved, straight/flat, or both.

                                                                                                          • Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Sep 18, 2018 Sep 18, 2018 at 0:19
                                                                                                            PSSS: Tautological implication means all the premises can be contradictory, and the argument is strong; it involves premisory conjunction implicating the conclusion, which can be false & strong at the same time. If all the premises are false; the argument is strong, regardless of the conclusion, due to the tautological implication.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            P(1): 1 + 1 = ⊞

                                                                                                            C(0)∴ No one is more intelligent than me!!! :D

                                                                                                            View in discussion
                                                                                                          • Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Sep 18, 2018 Sep 18, 2018 at 8:11
                                                                                                            🖖 Hello Mark,
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Person 1s' global warming argument is appeal to authority (human error), and normative bandwagoning; consensus is within the interval (50%,100%].
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            NASA spaceships (Links to an external site.) have exploded, killing all aboard, when a minority of authorities expressed ignored warnings; these events could be avoided by use of critical reasoning skills, since some employees will do any"-thing" to produce results sooner, rather than later ∵ it makes them look good for their next promotion, which they also want sooner, rather than later; even if these decisions could cost them their careers, since they'ren't using critical reasoning skills in their assessment of risk versus reward (desperate times call for desperate measures; using the apparent state of the economy as an apology for desperation, even though they are employed, and aren't tholing penury).

                                                                                                          • Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Shyam Nath
                                                                                                            Sep 18, 2018 Sep 18, 2018 at 11:23
                                                                                                            PSSSS: There're other techniques for (dis)proving arguments.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Argument Structure

                                                                                                            P = P(1) ∧ P(2) ∧ P(3) ∧ …

                                                                                                            Q = C(0)
                                                                                                            P → Q
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Direct Proofs
                                                                                                            Assume P is true
                                                                                                            Deduce Q is true
                                                                                                            ∵ P → Q
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Contrapositive Proofs
                                                                                                            Assume Q is false
                                                                                                            Deduce P is false
                                                                                                            ∵ (P → Q) = (¬Q → ¬P)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Contradictory Proofs
                                                                                                            Assume P is true
                                                                                                            Assume Q is false
                                                                                                            Disprove P ∧ Q
                                                                                                            ∵ (P → Q) = ¬(P ∧ ¬Q)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Trivial Proofs
                                                                                                            Trivially true when ⊨Q(x)
                                                                                                            ∵ ∀x: P(x) → Q(x)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Vacuous Proofs
                                                                                                            Vacuously true when ⊭P(x)
                                                                                                            ∵ ∀x: P(x) → Q(x)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Counterexample Disproofs
                                                                                                            Prove ¬P
                                                                                                            ∵ ¬P → P
                                                                                                            :  T → F = F
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Inductive Proofs
                                                                                                            (P(1) ∧ (∀k: P(k) → P(k + 1))) → (∀n: P(n)), where k ≥ 1 ≤ n
                                                                                                            (This is W4 stuff; I haven't started yet, so it's above my adroitness…)
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            Food For Thought
                                                                                                            I've noted, out of pure interest/ambition/ETC:
                                                                                                             ‣ Predicate Calculus uses: (Automated) Theorem Proving software, and inference engine design for knowledge-based (expert) systems.
                                                                                                             ‣ Proof By Induction uses: Some theorems concerning properties of integers, and with applications to algorithm analysis.
                                                                                                             
                                                                                                            IDK what it all means, but I'm excited nonetheless!!! :D
                                                                                                            Edited by Shyam Nath on Sep 18, 2018 at 11:57
